title: Tipo de cambio hoy en Perú: ¿En cuánto cerró el dólar este martes 6 de mayo?
content: Sigue en Gestión.pe la cotización del dólar hoy en Perú y conoce cuánto opera la divisa estadounidense en el mercado paralelo.
resumen: El martes 6 de mayo, el dólar en Perú cerró el día con un descenso, en el inicio de una semana que estará marcada por la reunión de política monetaria de la Reserva Federal de Estados Unidos. El tipo de cambio empezó el día en S/ 3.656. El lunes cerró la jornada S/ 3.666 con datos oficiales del Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (BCRP). Durante el año en curso, el dólar ha registrado una caída acumulada del 2.79% en comparación con su última cotización de 2024, que fue de S/ 3.761. En el mercado paralelo o las principales casas de cambio el dólar se compra a S/ 3.790 y se vende a S/ 3.810, según datos del portal cuantoestaeldolar.pe. La cotización promedio en el mercado bancario se coloca en S/ 3.795 a la compra y S/ 3.806 a la venta. La Fed mantendría las tasas de interés el miércoles, algo que podría cambiar en las próximas reuniones. La Fed ha mantenido su tipo oficial entre el 4.25% y el 4.50% desde diciembre y se proyectan dos recortes este año.

title: Caen inversiones de compañías españolas en Latinoamérica
content: Un 63% de empresas españolas aumentarán sus inversiones en Latinoamérica este año, pero la cifra es un descenso significativo ...
resumen:
Un 63% de empresas españolas aumentarán sus inversiones en Latinoamérica este año, pero la cifra es un descenso significativo en comparación con los últimos años, cuando la cifra solía rondar 75%, precisó un informe anual de IE University, titulado ‘Panorama de Inversión Española en Iberoamérica 2025’.
Otro 30% de las empresas española prevé mantener sus inversiones en Latinoamérica y 7% las disminuirán, de acuerdo con El Nacional.
En el caso de las empresas pequeñas y medianas (pymes), solo la mitad considera aumentar su apuesta por la región, un descenso “brusco” respecto a 80% de años anteriores.
México será el país más “afectado económicamente” por su alta exposición a Estados Unidos, sin embargo, volverá a ser donde más empresas españolas aumentarán sus inversiones, seguido por Colombia, y Chile, Perú y Brasil.
También subirán en Costa Rica y Paraguay, y se mantendrán en el resto en general.

title: Peña estuvo en foro con secretario del Tesoro, encargado de sanciones
content: No hubo una reunión oficial con Scott Bessent, aunque ambos se encontraron en EEUU. El presidente habló de Paraguay como una economía estable. Tiene previsto retornar hoy al país.
resumen: Santiago Peña participó en el Foro Global del Instituto Milken en Los Ángeles, donde se encontró con Scott Bessent, secretario del Tesoro de los Estados Unidos, encargado de la Oficina de Control de Activos Extranjeros (OFAC), que gestiona las sanciones económicas. Peña habló de Paraguay como una economía estable y atractiva para inversiones. No hubo una reunión oficial con Bessent debido a la agenda apretada. Peña expuso sobre las bondades de Paraguay para atraer inversiones, mencionando la "estabilidad" económica. El Gobierno de Peña tuvo una relación conflictiva con Estados Unidos antes de Donald Trump, debido a las designaciones de corrupción que afectaron a Horacio Cartes y las sanciones económicas a empresas ligadas a Cartes. El objetivo de Peña fue levantar esas sanciones. Peña no tuvo ninguna reunión con Bessent, quien habló sobre asuntos comerciales y proteccionismo. Peña conversó con Richard Grenell, enviado para Misiones Especiales de Donald Trump, sobre seguridad, cooperación internacional e inversiones estratégicas. Peña retorna hoy de su gira. El alineamiento de Peña a Trump no tuvo gran efecto hasta el momento. No se levantaron las sanciones y no hay embajador estadounidense en Asunción ni representante paraguayo en Washington. title: “Canadá nunca estará en venta”: Carney, en encuentro con Trump, rechazó idea de que su país sea el estado 51 de EE. UU.
content: El primer ministro de Canadá, Mark Carney, aseguró el martes frente a Donald Trump que su país “nunca estará en venta”, durante una reunión en la ...
resumen:
El primer ministro de Canadá, Mark Carney, aseguró el martes frente a Donald Trump que su país “nunca estará en venta”, durante una reunión en la Casa Blanca en medio de tensiones sobre aranceles y soberanía.
En su primer encuentro en la Oficina Oval, Trump insistió al recientemente elegido Carney que sería un “matrimonio maravilloso” si Canadá aceptara sus repetidos llamados para convertirse en el estado número 51 de Estados Unidos.
Carney afirmó haberle pedido a Trump en privado que dejara de insistir en que Canadá se anexe a Estados Unidos.
En la Oficina Oval, le había subrayado al magnate inmobiliario Trump que “hay lugares que nunca están en venta”.
Carney, líder del Partido Liberal, de 60 años, ganó las elecciones canadienses del 28 de abril con la promesa de plantar cara al republicano Trump, de 78 años.
Carney y Trump hablaron en un tono “positivo”.
Carney declaró en rueda de prensa que las negociaciones comerciales son “complejas”, pero que sus conversaciones de dos horas con Trump fueron “muy constructivas”.
Carney afirmó que le había pedido a Trump que dejara de instar a Canadá a ser su estado número 51.
Trump afirmó que no hubo tensión durante la reunión, que calificó de “magnífica”.
Trump impuso aranceles a Canadá y México, salvo para los productos incluidos en el Tratado de libre comercio de América del Norte (T-MEC).
Anteriormente, Carney fue gobernador del Banco de Canadá y del Banco de Inglaterra.

title: Sorpresa y rechazo: Hollywood se opone a los aranceles de Trump
content: Hollywood reaccionó con preocupación y sorpresa al anuncio del 100% de aranceles que el presidente Donald Trump pretende aplicar a todas las películas producidas fuera ...
resumen: Hollywood reaccionó con preocupación y sorpresa al anuncio del 100% de aranceles que el presidente Donald Trump pretende aplicar a todas las películas producidas fuera de Estados Unidos que se estrenen en su territorio. La impresión generalizada es que el plan de Trump no solo no funcionará, sino que empeorará la actual situación, teniendo en cuenta la gran cantidad de proyectos de pequeño, mediano y gran presupuesto que se diseñan y se ruedan en el extranjero. Randy Greenberg, productor de títulos taquilleros como Megalodón o Cowboys & Aliens, escribió que aplicar un arancel a las películas filmadas fuera de Estados Unidos aumentará el coste de rodaje. Los analistas del banco de inversión Morgan Stanley calificaron la idea de Donald Trump de «mal definida» y explicaron que la imposición de aranceles del 100 % sobre una parte o sobre la totalidad del coste de una producción deslocalizada de Hollywood «conduciría a que haya menos películas, películas más caras y menores ganancias para todos en la industria». Álvar Carretero, productor y publicista de la firma Joshua Jason, explica que la noticia ha causado muchísimo desconcierto. El anuncio del Gobierno de la República Popular China, que recortará el número de películas estadounidenses que permitirá estrenar en sus salas de cine tras la guerra arancelaria iniciada por Washington hace unas semanas. En Hollywood, la producción de películas, series y anuncios descendió un 22,4% en los primeros tres meses del año, de acuerdo a los datos de FilmLA. El primer trimestre de 2025 se cerró con un descenso del 11% en taquilla, según datos de Box Office Mojo. title: 100 días de espejismo: la victoria ilusoria de Donald Trump
content: A cien días de su regreso al poder, Donald Trump presume de una deslumbrante victoria económica. Pero detrás de las cifras halagüeñas se esconde una realidad mucho más oscura: aumento de la desigualda ...
resumen:
A cien días de su regreso al poder, Donald Trump presume de una deslumbrante victoria económica. Pero detrás de las cifras halagüeñas se esconde una realidad mucho más oscura: aumento de la desigualdad, retroceso ecológico, inestabilidad geopolítica y regresión social. Estados Unidos tambalea y el mundo siente las consecuencias.

Ciertamente, Estados Unidos muestra un crecimiento económico insolente y un bajo desempleo. Pero la derrota de los demócratas en las elecciones de noviembre de 2024 se explica en gran medida por la insatisfacción de los estadounidenses con el costo de vida, un problema que Trump, pese a su entusiasmo espectacular, no ha logrado resolver.

Desde los años 90, el PIB per cápita en EE.UU. ha aumentado más del 60%, frente al 38% de la eurozona y el 34% de Francia. Pero esa brecha oculta profundas fisuras: el PIB no refleja ni la calidad de vida, ni la desigualdad social, ni el estado de los servicios públicos.

El estadounidense promedio sufre bajo un sistema que no comprende. Los salarios parecen altos sobre el papel, pero los costos de la salud, la educación y la vivienda son astronómicos.

Pese al crecimiento, la inflación devora el día a día y la desigualdad se dispara. Desde 2016 (excluyendo el periodo del COVID), el país ha vivido niveles históricamente bajos de desempleo, pero eso no ha bastado para cerrar la brecha entre clases sociales. A esto se suman un déficit público crónico (6,1% del PIB en promedio desde 1995) y un gigantesco déficit comercial agravado por políticas proteccionistas —de Trump y también de Biden.

En lo ambiental, el panorama es igualmente alarmante. Estados Unidos ha sido históricamente el mayor emisor mundial de gases de efecto invernadero. El regreso de Donald Trump al poder, con sus órdenes ejecutivas simbólicas y destructivas, es una mala señal: reinicia la explotación de combustibles fósiles, socava los esfuerzos climáticos e incluso revive proyectos de minería en aguas profundas, teóricamente protegidos por el derecho internacional.

A nivel interno, Trump sigue una agenda brutal: recortes de impuestos para los más ricos, eliminación de miles de empleos públicos, política migratoria endurecida, negacionismo científico y ataques a la Reserva Federal. No hay coherencia estratégica.

Internacionalmente, las tensiones aumentan: Ucrania, Rusia, Gaza, Burkina Faso sin contar la crisis interna en los propios servicios de inteligencia estadounidenses.

Trump y Musk: un dúo en declive. Este tándem improbable —símbolo del desvío tecnocrático y populista— enfrenta hoy sus límites. Elon Musk, atrapado por las pérdidas de Tesla, renunció a su liderazgo en DOGE. Donald Trump, por su parte, sigue acumulando fracasos, y las elecciones de medio mandato se acercan peligrosamente.

Las consecuencias ya se sienten: Los recortes presupuestarios podrían provocar una caída de la demanda y de la recaudación fiscal. La obsesión antiinmigración priva a la economía de mano de obra esencial, con efectos esperados sobre el crecimiento y la inflación. El cambio climático se intensifica, sin una estrategia creíble de adaptación. El alza de aranceles podría obligar a la Fed a subir tasas de interés, ralentizando la economía. La brecha de riqueza se agranda: los ricos son más ricos, los modestos más pobres. La inestabilidad financiera crece: ataques a la Fed, volatilidad del dólar y un Wall Street tambaleante.

Según el CEPII, la política comercial de Trump podría provocar una caída del 3,3% en el comercio mundial —el 70% del colapso registrado durante la crisis del COVID. Europa y China se ven atrapadas en una reconfiguración brutal de alianzas económicas.

Europa —y Francia en particular— podría recibir un golpe duro: las industrias automotriz, aeroespacial, farmacéutica, de bebidas y química son especialmente vulnerables. La importación masiva de gas natural licuado (GNL) desde Estados Unidos —cuatro veces más contaminante que el noruego— es un ejemplo inquietante. Ante estos riesgos, Europa debe actuar: repensar su industria, construir un mercado interno más resiliente, invertir en eficiencia energética y reforzar su soberanía estratégica.

El aumento planificado de la producción de combustibles fósiles en EE.UU. representa una amenaza ambiental mayor. El metano —un gas de efecto invernadero 25 veces más potente que el CO2— se libera masivamente durante el transporte del GNL. Como resultado, el GNL estadounidense es hasta cuatro veces más contaminante que el importado desde Noruega.

Donald Trump lanza ahora una nueva confrontación en el mar, iniciando proyectos de minería en aguas profundas, a pesar de las protecciones del derecho internacional que declaran esas zonas patrimonio común de la humanidad.

Toda crisis económica golpea primero a mujeres y niños. Las políticas de Trump —hostiles a la salud, la investigación y la ayuda internacional— debilitan directamente a los más vulnerables. En sectores como la salud y la educación, mayoritariamente femeninos, los recortes presupuestarios tienen efectos devastadores. En Estados Unidos, como en otros países, los derechos reproductivos retroceden, la violencia aumenta y la precariedad se instala.

Al socavar la solidaridad global, la política trumpista amenaza la estabilidad de la salud pública mundial. Y los riesgos sanitarios son enormes. La pandemia del COVID-19 fue un recordatorio brutal: un virus no conoce fronteras, color de piel ni estatus social. Lamentablemente, las políticas que ignoran la cooperación internacional y la salud pública nos exponen a desastres sanitarios futuros.

title: ‘We Don’t Have to Sign Deals’: Trump Backs Off Big Promises About Tariffs
content: After weeks of bragging about upcoming trade “deals” with foreign countries, President Trump says the United States doesn’t need to worry about them after all.
resumen:
Desde que el presidente Trump anunció que impondría fuertes aranceles a países de todo el mundo, ha predicho que obligarían a los socios comerciales a firmar grandes acuerdos beneficiosos para Estados Unidos.

El martes, con el primer ministro canadiense sentado a su lado en la Oficina Oval y sin que se lograra un nuevo acuerdo comercial entre los dos países, el Sr. Trump tenía un mensaje diferente para el público: "No tenemos que firmar acuerdos".

"Todo el mundo dice '¿Cuándo, cuándo, cuándo vas a firmar acuerdos?'", dijo el Sr. Trump, en un momento dado, señalando a Howard Lutnick, el secretario de comercio. "No tenemos que firmar acuerdos. Podríamos firmar 25 acuerdos ahora mismo, Howard, si quisiéramos. No tenemos que firmar acuerdos. Ellos tienen que firmar acuerdos con nosotros. Quieren nuestro mercado. No queremos una parte de su mercado. No nos importa su mercado".

A los pocos días del anuncio del 2 de abril de los aranceles generalizados, funcionarios de la Casa Blanca dijeron que alrededor de 70 países ya estaban llamando para llegar a acuerdos. El asesor comercial del Sr. Trump predijo que habría 90 acuerdos en 90 días.

Pero más de un mes después, tales acuerdos no se han materializado. Y el tiempo corre.

El Sr. Trump predijo que los primeros acuerdos podrían firmarse esta semana. Pero los funcionarios de la administración también hicieron esa predicción la semana anterior a esa, y la semana anterior a esa.

El martes, el presidente dijo a los miembros de la prensa reunidos a su alrededor que pronto haría un anuncio importante, pero advirtió que podría no ser un acuerdo comercial.

"Siguen escribiendo sobre acuerdos, acuerdos, '¿cuándo vamos a firmar?'", dijo el Sr. Trump, sonando molesto por las preguntas de los reporteros.

En otro momento se desahogó: "Ojalá dejaran de preguntar cuántos acuerdos vas a firmar esta semana".

Entonces el Sr. Trump pareció cambiar la definición misma de un acuerdo de un acuerdo bilateral a una demanda unilateral.

En las dos semanas siguientes, dijo el presidente, se sentaría con sus principales asesores y haría "acuerdos" unilaterales que la administración anunciaría sin la participación de otros países.

"Un día vendremos y les daremos 100 acuerdos", dijo el presidente.

En el Capitolio, Scott Bessent, el secretario del Tesoro, adoptando un tono menos desenfadado, dijo que algunos acuerdos comerciales podrían anunciarse esta semana.

El Sr. Bessent dijo a un comité de la Cámara de Representantes que estaba negociando con 17 socios comerciales importantes, pero no con China, la economía más grande del mundo después de Estados Unidos.

"Muchos de nuestros socios comerciales se han acercado a nosotros con muy buenas ofertas", dijo.

La negociación de acuerdos comerciales es notoriamente compleja y requiere mucho tiempo.

El Instituto Peterson de Economía Internacional dijo en un análisis de 2016 que las negociaciones para un solo acuerdo comercial a menudo pueden tomar más de un año, mientras que la implementación puede tomar varios años.

Y para los acuerdos comerciales que el Sr. Trump sí alcanza, puede amargarse rápidamente. El principal acuerdo comercial de su primer mandato fue el Acuerdo Estados Unidos-México-Canadá, que el presidente ahora dice que quiere renegociar.

title: Rep. Suzan DelBene on Tariffs, Trade Policy, and Congressional Authority
content: "I've been very vocal about congressional authority under a Democratic president or now under a Republican president," the Washington state congresswoman tells Reason.
resumen:
Las tarifas que el presidente Donald Trump anunció el 2 de abril sobre prácticamente todas las importaciones costarían alrededor de $3.1 billones en los próximos 10 años, y serían un aumento de impuestos de $2,100 por hogar solo en 2025 según la estimación de la Tax Foundation, lo que las convierte en uno de los mayores aumentos de impuestos en la historia de Estados Unidos si alguna vez entran en pleno efecto.

La Constitución deja claro que solo el Congreso tiene el poder de aumentar los impuestos, y la representante Suzan DelBene (D–Wash.) cree que Trump está extralimitándose en su autoridad. En febrero, presentó un proyecto de ley que prohíbe a los presidentes usar poderes económicos de emergencia para imponer aranceles sin el consentimiento del Congreso.

DelBene se reunió con Eric Boehm de Reason en marzo para discutir el impacto de los aranceles y el papel que el Congreso debería desempeñar en el establecimiento de la política comercial.

DelBene: Cuando [Trump] tiene aranceles como este en vigor, en realidad está impactando a los fabricantes nacionales que necesitan piezas de su producto que provengan de Canadá o México. Esto impacta a los fabricantes de automóviles. Impacta a la industria aeroespacial, que es grande en mi distrito. Y a veces la gente vende sus piezas a Canadá o México como parte de la producción que podría estar ocurriendo allí. Así que es increíblemente disruptivo, y eso es solo la manufactura.

Y podría señalar que es fácil romper cosas. Es fácil quitar mercados. Es difícil recuperarlos. Y así, esta idea de que podrías simplemente encenderlos y apagarlos y que nada cambie es absolutamente falsa. La gente tardará años y años en tratar de recuperar el acceso al mercado. Y solo la amenaza de los aranceles ya ha impactado la capacidad de las empresas estadounidenses para exportar a estos países.

DelBene: En primer lugar, estos son aliados. Estas no son naciones extranjeras hostiles. Y tenemos un acuerdo comercial con [México y Canadá]. Así que tengo legislación para dejar claro que el Congreso realmente tiene la autoridad cuando se trata de aranceles, comercio e impuestos, y que si el presidente, cualquier presidente, quiere poner en vigor aranceles tan amplios, tiene que acudir al Congreso y obtener la aprobación del Congreso. Eso es lo que dice la Constitución.

Y de nuevo, estos son nuestros aliados. Hay un acuerdo comercial, y tiene una [cláusula] de solución de controversias. Entonces, si crees que hay algo que deba abordarse, deberías estar utilizando el acuerdo comercial existente que está en vigor para abordar cualquier disputa que pueda haber. No lo ha hecho. Fue directamente a declarar estos aranceles generalizados que van a ser devastadores económicamente para las familias de todo el país.

DelBene: Sí. Creo que el Congreso tiene que asegurarse de ejercer esta autoridad. Necesitamos que quede claro en el estatuto. Y esto no es una declaración sobre ninguna administración en particular. Cuando hablamos de impuestos y de si subimos o bajamos los impuestos, el Congreso tiene autoridad allí. El Congreso es una rama independiente y coigual del gobierno, y el Congreso necesita decir: "Estas no son cosas que la rama ejecutiva pueda decidir unilateralmente".

DelBene: Absolutamente. He sido muy vocal sobre la autoridad del Congreso bajo un presidente demócrata o ahora bajo un presidente republicano. Y, francamente, hay muchos miembros republicanos de la Cámara que fueron muy vocales bajo el presidente [Joe] Biden sobre lo importante que era que el Congreso tuviera voz. Y ahora están en silencio. Así que ahí es donde está la hipocresía.

title: US electric vehicle market amid trade and policy uncertainty
content: US President Trump recently imposed a 145% tariff on Chinese goods, which include electric vehicle (EV) components.
resumen: The US EV market is facing uncertainty due to trade and policy shifts. Both the Biden and Trump administrations aimed to reduce reliance on Chinese-made vehicles, but their strategies differ. The ongoing US-China trade war is negatively impacting the US EV market, particularly due to dependence on Chinese imports like lithium-ion batteries. US EV manufacturers struggle to compete with cost-competitive Chinese EVs. Trump's broader rollback of EV-friendly policies poses a threat to future domestic sales. In 2024, the Biden administration imposed a 100% tariff on Chinese EVs and a 25% tariff on lithium-ion EV batteries. The Biden administration set a goal that 50% of all new vehicles sold in the US by 2030 would be battery electric vehicles (BEVs). The Biden Administration focused on infrastructure development, allocating $5bn under the National Electric Vehicle Infrastructure (NEVI) Formula Program to build a nationwide network of 500,000 high-speed EV charging stations by 2030, and strengthening the domestic battery manufacturing sector. In September 2024, the US DoE announced over $3bn in funding for 25 projects across 14 states. Trump recently imposed a 145% tariff on Chinese goods, including EV components. China controls around 60% of global rare earth elements (REE) mining and 90% of its processing. US-built vehicles rely heavily on international supply chains. Tesla imports 20% to 25% of its components from other countries. Tesla’s stock has fallen nearly 50% from its December 2024 peak. BYD surpassed Tesla in global EV sales in Q4 2024, delivering 594,839 units, versus Tesla’s 491,062. The imposition of tariffs has led to diplomatic friction. The Trump administration has granted temporary exemptions for certain automakers. In March 2025, it issued a one-month reprieve from tariffs for companies including Ford, General Motors, and Stellantis. On April 29, Trump suggested he would ease tariffs affecting car production costs. Tesla has made major investments in lithium-ion battery production at its Gigafactory in Nevada. The US is ramping up domestic battery production, ranking second globally with 91 lithium-ion EV battery plants due to come online between 2025 and 2032. China has over 277 upcoming lithium-ion battery plants set to reach completion between 2025 and 2032. Plans to ease fuel economy and CO₂ reduction targets would reduce the pressure on automakers to invest in electrification technologies. The administration’s intent to eliminate the $7,500 federal EV tax credit could drastically reduce EV demand. Several battery investments have already been delayed or canceled, including LG’s Queen Creek plant in Arizona and the HL-GA Battery Company plant in Georgia.

title: How will Canada’s new prime minister affect New York?
content: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney has a mandate to fight back against the Trump administration’s attacks on our northern neighbor – and New York could be caught in the middle.
resumen:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney has a mandate to fight back against the Trump administration’s attacks on our northern neighbor – and New York could be caught in the middle.

The trade war between America and Canada has already had significant impacts on New York industries from agriculture to manufacturing, and if the situation spirals, especially following Carney’s meeting with President Donald Trump on Tuesday, it could make things even worse for the state.

Chris Kirkey, director of the Center for the Study of Canada and Institute on Québec Studies at SUNY Plattsburgh, believes that Carney won’t let things escalate.

Kirkey told City & State: “Mark Carney is committed to trade with New York and trade with the United States. He's not a protectionist. He's one who believes in the value of markets, but particularly free markets.”

Assembly Member Billy Jones said that even if Carney does manage to mend fences and repair the way that some Canadians are beginning to view the U.S. and New York, much of the economic damage is done.

Jones said that Canadian officials understand the situation that New York is in, but new policies in response to the trade war, like limiting barriers for interprovincial commerce and labor supply, are already in motion.

Gov. Kathy Hochul and other governors in the northeast also invited Canadian officials to the U.S. in a bid to strengthen cross border ties.

Rep. Josh Riley, who represents a large rural district in upstate New York, is hopeful that Carney will recognize the situation and negotiate for a more equitable trade agreement.

Riley said: “My hope is that this summer, when the United States, Mexico and Canada trade agreement is up for review, there's an opportunity there to renegotiate some parts of it in a way that does two things: first, provide certainty and support for Upstate New York's farmers, and then second, brings good manufacturing jobs back home.”

Chris Kirkey said: “I think New York has to just once again remind folks that this relationship is really a positive one for New York state.”

title: Navigating in the dark
content: The businesses that rely on goods moving through California’s ports are about to feel the pain of Trump’s trade war.
resumen:
American manufacturers and retailers are anticipating a sharp drop-off in imports from China this week as they struggle to pay a 145 percent tariff on goods from the country.

Dozens of ships have canceled planned arrivals at West Coast ports.

Stephen Cheung, CEO of the Los Angeles County Economic Development Corp., says nobody is safe from the global economic upheaval.

Cheung had to lay off three people last week because the budget got cut.

The climate world — especially in the transportation and energy storage sectors that rely on lithium batteries — is particularly vulnerable to the pain.

Around a third of the cost of electric vehicles is their batteries, a market dominated by Chinese manufacturing.

Cheung said the confusion caused by Trump’s volatile trade policy is being compounded by the White House’s information void.

LAEDC isn’t in contact with Trump’s top trade advisers.

The nonprofit has turned to larger organizations like the International Economic Development Council, which has more than 4,500 members globally, to get its message across.

Gene Seroka, executive director of the Port of Los Angeles, said he anticipates a 35 percent decline in container deliveries this week, compared with the same point last year.

Prices of products made in China now are two and a half times more than they were just last month.

Senior Trump aides on the White House’s National Economic Council and in the Treasury Department are closely monitoring the disruption.

The California Building Industry Association is working with British Columbia officials to try to secure lumber supplies for rebuilding after the Los Angeles fires, while the U.S. Lumber Coalition is hoping for new tariffs on Canadian exports.

U.S. Lumber Coalition Executive Director Zoltan van Heyningen argues that Canadian producers are hurting the U.S. lumber industry by “dumping” their excess capacity in U.S. markets.

Dan Dunmoyer, president of the CBIA, is pushing back on van Heyningen’s claim that the domestic industry can deliver enough lumber in time to rebuild the Pacific Palisades and Altadena.

The industry currently sources about 30 percent of its lumber from Canada.

California-grown wine vineyards have struggled to stay in business amid years of declining consumption — and competition from European wine subsidized by the European Union.

Natalie Collins, president and CEO of the California Wine Growers, said there could be a real opportunity for them to essentially level the playing field.

The tariffs so far haven’t helped much because they’ve prompted retaliatory moves from California wine’s top export market, Canada.

Stuart Spencer, the executive director of the Lodi Winegrape Commission, said the uncertainty and the pulling the wine off of shelves in Canada has probably done more harm to California wine.

Trump resumed his bashing of California’s high-speed rail project today, while daring Gov. Gavin Newsom to run for president.

Trump told reporters after a White House meeting with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney that Newsom’s support for the decades-old rail project and his handling of the LA wildfires make him unelectable.

Newsom’s office in a statement slammed Trump for his tariff policies and his own business failures and said walking away from high-speed rail now would give China an infrastructure advantage.

The Federal Railroad Administration is close to completing an investigation into two federal grants to the project.

The cap-and-trade conversation is heating up around the Capitol.

The Environmental Defense Fund and Greenline Insights put out a report today modeling the program’s economic benefits, including the $200 each household making under $200,000 a year could save, if it’s extended through 2045.

A coalition of agricultural groups including the California Climate and Agriculture Network wants to see the share of revenues for ag-based climate programs boosted from 5 to 15 percent when the program is reauthorized.

A group that includes Southern California Edison, the ports, car companies and charging companies wants to see $10 billion in GGRF dollars allocated over the next three years to support transportation electrification in LA ahead of the 2028 Olympic Games.

Environmental groups celebrating Oceans Day today yet again trotted out their giant inflatable sea turtle on the steps of the Capitol building in Sacramento, earning a shoutout from Sen. Ben Allen.

Allen brought up his 2022 law to cut plastic waste.

Environmental groups are trying to unstick stalled negotiations over a declining Colorado River by pressing the Interior Department to invoke a little-used regulation to halt “current wasteful water uses” across Arizona, California and Nevada.

The Natural Resources Defense Council, represented by UCLA’s Frank G. Wells Environmental Law Clinic, unveiled their petition today in a letter to Interior Secretary Doug Burgum and the Bureau of Reclamation.

NRDC’s Mark Gold said it seemed like this was a good time to file this in order to catalyze some sort of meaningful discussion moving forward.

Natural Resources Secretary Wade Crowfoot is mingling with counterparts from regions of Australia, Spain, Chile, South Africa, Greece and Morocco at a conference in Cape Town this week to take stock one year after the formal launch of a partnership between subnational governments with Mediterranean climates to exchange wildfire and drought technologies and policy ideas.

title: Trade Talks With China Have Not Started, Bessent Says
content: The Treasury secretary said that trade deals with other U.S. trading partners could be announced as soon as this week.
resumen:
El secretario del Tesoro, Scott Bessent, dijo el martes que Estados Unidos podría anunciar acuerdos comerciales con los principales socios comerciales tan pronto como esta semana, pero que no han comenzado las negociaciones con China sobre los aranceles.

Los comentarios se produjeron cuando el Sr. Bessent testificaba ante un comité de la Cámara de Representantes y respondía preguntas sobre el estado de la economía estadounidense y la agenda comercial del presidente Trump. Los aranceles del Sr. Trump a China y a países de todo el mundo han provocado que los economistas reduzcan sus previsiones de crecimiento y adviertan sobre un nuevo episodio de inflación, pero el Sr. Bessent argumentó que las medidas conducirían en última instancia a que otros países redujeran sus barreras comerciales.

El secretario del Tesoro y el Sr. Trump han dicho durante semanas que muchas naciones estaban ansiosas por llegar a nuevos acuerdos comerciales que se anunciarían pronto, aunque hasta ahora no se ha materializado ninguno. El mes pasado, el Sr. Trump sugirió que también se había puesto en contacto con el líder de China, Xi Jinping, pero los funcionarios chinos insistieron en que no se estaban produciendo tales conversaciones.

El martes, el Sr. Bessent fue claro: "China, aún no hemos entablado negociaciones".

Las negociaciones con varias naciones comenzaron el mes pasado después de que el Sr. Trump impusiera un arancel universal del 10 por ciento a las importaciones de todos los países y aranceles adicionales que describió como "recíprocos" a docenas de ellos. Esos aranceles adicionales se han suspendido mientras se llevan a cabo las negociaciones.

No estaba claro si los acuerdos comerciales serían pactos formales o declaraciones de entendimiento mutuo sobre los términos comerciales revisados.

El Sr. Bessent trató de defender la política comercial del Sr. Trump, defendiendo los aranceles como necesarios para solucionar los desequilibrios comerciales. "Nuestro objetivo es un comercio justo para recuperar empleos de fabricación de precisión bien remunerados en los EE. UU.", dijo a los legisladores.

El Sr. Bessent también desestimó las previsiones que sugerían que el país se dirigía hacia una recesión. Dijo que los datos económicos no sugerían que la economía se estuviera contrayendo y predijo que los decepcionantes datos de crecimiento del primer trimestre se revisarían al alza.

title: Trump says the US will stop bombing Yemen’s Houthis after rebels say they’ll stop targeting ships
content: WASHINGTON (AP) — President Donald Trump said Tuesday that he’s ordering a halt to nearly two months of U.S. airstrikes on Yemen’s Houthis, saying the Iran-backed rebels have indicated that “they ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump said Tuesday that he’s ordering a halt to nearly two months of U.S. airstrikes on Yemen’s Houthis, saying the Iran-backed rebels have indicated that “they don’t want to fight anymore” and have pledged to stop attacking ships along a vital global trade route.

Trump said the Houthis had indicated to U.S. officials that “they don’t want to fight anymore. They just don’t want to fight. And we will honor that, and we will stop the bombings.”

The campaign of airstrikes began in March, when Trump promised to use “overwhelming lethal force” after the Houthis said they would resume attacks on Israeli vessels sailing off Yemen in response to Israel’s mounting another blockade on the Gaza Strip.

Trump’s announcement came the same day that Israel’s military launched airstrikes against the Houthis that it said fully disabled the international airport in the Yemeni capital, Sanaa. Israel’s attacks were its second round of airstrikes on targets in Yemen in retaliation for a Houthi missile strike Sunday on Israel’s international airport.

Trump said the Houthis had “capitulated but, more importantly, we will take their word that they say they will not be blowing up ships anymore. And that’s what the purpose of what we were doing,” Trump said.

Omani Foreign Minister Badr al-Busaidi, confirmed that the U.S. bombing campaign was ending, posting on X that discussions involving the U.S. and Oman, as well as negotiators in Yemen, “have resulted in a ceasefire agreement between the two sides.”

“In the future, neither side will target the other, including American vessels, in the Red Sea and Bab al-Mandab Strait, ensuring freedom of navigation and the smooth flow of international commercial shipping,” he wrote.

Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said on social media that Trump’s “objective from Day One: ‘ensuring freedom of navigation.’ PEACE THRU STRENGTH in action.”

From November 2023 until January 2025, the Houthis targeted more than 100 merchant vessels with missiles and drones, sinking two of them and killing four sailors. That has greatly reduced the flow of trade through the Red Sea corridor, which typically sees $1 trillion of goods move through it annually.

The Trump-ordered airstrikes gained a higher profile in the public consciousness when The Atlantic revealed that Hegseth had texted sensitive plans for a military strike against the Houthis on a group chat in the messaging app Signal that mistakenly included the magazine’s editor-in-chief.

National security adviser Mike Waltz, who created the group chat on Signal, left his post last week and has been nominated by Trump to be the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations.

title: Trump says US should to stop ‘subsidising’ Canada as trade talks continue
content: The US leader says it’s hard to justify the US$200 billion deficit, including defence spending benefiting the nation.
resumen: WASHINGTON: President Donald Trump on Tuesday said the US should stop “subsidising” Canada, as he hosted the country’s recently reelected premier Mark Carney for talks in Washington. Canada has been caught up in the new administration’s stop-start tariff rollout, which has hit goods not covered under an existing free trade arrangement with levies of up to 25%. Canada’s autos, steel, and aluminum exports have also been hit by the tariffs. “We have a tremendous deficit with Canada,” Trump told reporters during an event at the White House, with Carney seated just a few feet away. “It’s hard to justify subsidising Canada to the tune of maybe US$200 billion a year,” he said, adding: “We protect Canada militarily, and we always will.” The US’ trade deficit with Canada was US$63.3 billion last year, according to the US trade representative’s office. The far higher figure of US$200 billion often cited by Trump also takes into account how much US defence spending benefits Canada, a member of the Trump transition team told CNN in mid-January, ahead of his return to office. Returning to the issue of trade, Trump said America’s northern neighbour would soon have to “take care of itself economically.” “We don’t really want cars from Canada, and we put tariffs on cars from Canada,” he said. “And at a certain point, it won’t make economic sense for Canada to build those cars.” “We really don’t want Canadian steel, and we don’t want Canadian aluminium and various other things, because we want to be able to do it ourselves,” he added. The White House previously estimated that around 38% of Canadian imports to the US and around half of all Mexican imports, are covered by the existing US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) and are currently not subject to the sweeping tariffs. A large part of Canada’s US imports not covered by the USMCA exemption are energy products, which currently face a lower 10% tariff rate. The USMCA is due for review next year.

title: Trump's tariffs are hurting Tennesseans and the local economy. Here's how | Opinion
content: From job losses and increased costs related to reduced exports, Tennesseans will only be harmed by Trump's tariffs ...
resumen: Economists widely disagree with tariffs as effective economic policy, citing potential harm to efficient industries and overall economic growth. Tariffs are also likely to raise consumer prices and cause job losses in sectors reliant on imports. Tariffs can negatively impact Tennessee's manufacturing and export-heavy economy, affecting industries like automotive and medical equipment. Over 1,700 economists disagree with tariffs, seeing no credible economic justification for them, and warning that they will only prop up inefficient producers at the expense of more efficient industries. This will undermine economic efficiency, employment, and wage growth in Tennessee. Economists aren’t convinced by any of the three justifications the Trump Administration advances for tariffs. If Trump’s goal is job protectionism, then tariffs must be high enough to force Americans to buy American. If revenue is the goal, then tariffs must be low enough so Americans will still pay the tax, which means they will not protect American jobs. If negotiation towards free trade is the goal, then neither job nor revenue objectives will be achieved. Tariffs protect some American jobs in a few sectors by destroying far more American jobs in other sectors. Dockworkers, truckers, and delivery drivers are the first Americans to lose their jobs under tariffs. Next comes job losses at American firms that import inputs, such as materials, parts, and compounds, to produce goods and services. Nearly 60% of our imports are inputs, so tariffs will substantially raise costs for American companies. These costs will be passed along to consumers, resulting in fewer sales and, thus, job loss. Steel tariffs to protect jobs in the steel industry caused massive job losses in the American automobile, motorcycle, and farming equipment sectors. Tariffs slash foreign investment in the American economy. Tariffs make American goods and services more expensive, hurting our exporting industries and reducing foreign investment in our country. Retaliatory tariffs, which can be expected, only serve to amplify these losses. Tariffs are a tax paid by American consumers. Tariffs tend to be a regressive tax because a set tax will fall heavier on the budgets of the poor than the wealthy. No credible estimates come even close to raising enough revenue. America has some of the highest tariffs and non-tariff barriers among our major trading partners. Trump started negotiations not by lowering our tariffs to match our trading partners but by jacking them up across the board. He ripped up previous trade agreements, including one he signed and declared “the fairest, most balanced, and beneficial trade agreement” ever. Countries like India, China, and Vietnam—with per capita GDPs of only $2,500, $12,500, and $4,300 (compared to nearly $83,000 for the US)—won’t be buying our automobiles anytime soon. Tennessee’s economy, heavily tied to manufacturing and exports, suffers from these ripple effects. The state exported nearly $40 billion in goods in 2024, including $4.25 billion in medical instruments, $2.63 billion in automobiles, and $2.26 billion in computers. Roughly 1/5th of Tennessee’s jobs are driven by international trade. Trump’s 2025 “Liberation Day” tariffs can be expected to slash exports, raise input costs, and reduce competitiveness for firms like Nissan in Smyrna, Jack Daniels in Lynchburg, or Bridgestone in La Vergne. A recent Goldman Sachs report estimated that a 10% tariff alone could destroy five U.S. jobs for every job created, even without retaliation. The U.S. is manufacturing more than it ever has in inflation-adjusted terms. We are the second-largest exporter of manufactured goods in the world and the largest exporter of services. Automation is allowing people worldwide to move out of mundane, low-skilled jobs. Daniel J. Smith is the Director of the Political Economy Research Institute and Professor of Economics at Middle Tennessee State University.

title: Mattel Says It’s Going to Raise Prices After Trump Says Americans Don’t Need So Many Dolls
content: As far as its efforts to address tariffs, Kreiz said that the company is also focused on diversifying its global supply chain to reduce its reliance on China. The Mattel chief claimed in the ...
resumen: Mattel CEO Ynon Kreiz cast doubt on the notion that Mattel might move its manufacturing to the United States in light of President Trump’s tariffs on Chinese goods in an appearance on CNBC’s “Squawk Box” on Tuesday. Mattel does see rising prices in the US. Kreiz cited three key strategies the company is deploying to mitigate the costs of Trump’s trade war, with “pricing action,” among them. Mattel withdrew its annual financial forecast, explaining in its first quarter earnings report that, “Given the volatile macroeconomic environment and evolving U.S. tariff landscape, it is difficult to predict consumer spending and Mattel’s U.S. sales in the remainder of the year and holiday season.” Mattel also said it had raised its cost savings target for the year from $60 million to $80 million, part of which would be achieved by cutting promotions and discounts. The company also laid off more than one hundred employees from its Headquarters in El Segundo, CA, at the end of March. Kreiz said that the company is also focused on diversifying its global supply chain to reduce its reliance on China. In two years, no single country will represent more than 25% of Mattel’s sourcing. Mattel also imports products (which include Barbies, Hot Wheels, and American Girl Dolls) from Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand. Those countries were also the targets of reciprocal tariffs announced by the Trump administration in early April before being paused for 90 days. President Trump addressed the impact tariffs would have on the toy industry (80% of global toy production takes place in China), saying in a cabinet meeting that, “Well, maybe the children will have two dolls instead of 30 dolls, you know? And maybe the two dolls will cost a couple of bucks more than they would normally.” Kreiz emphasized that Mattel is committed to producing a steady supply of product at a “wide range of affordable price points.” Roth analyst Eric Handler told CNBC that Mattel expects to keep between 40% and 50% of its products under $20. The Toy Association, a trade group representing the US toy industry, has pushed hard for an exemption from Trump’s tariffs since they were announced. Kreiz expressed his support for the group’s advocacy in the interview, saying that toys are “an essential part of children’s lives.” Kreiz came to Mattel in 2018 from Maker Studios. The Barbie brand posted its best full-year sales results of all time in 2021 under Krez’s leadership. Last week, speaking to reporters during a cabinet meeting, President Trump said that “maybe the children will have two dolls instead of 30 dolls,” this Christmas season.

title: Trump’s tariffs deal a blow to the bottom line of US companies
content: Businesses are suspending or lowering their earnings and profit forecasts due to uncertainty, higher costs, and an economic slowdown ...
resumen:
U.S. President Donald Trump is presenting the trade war as a way to protect American industry from foreign competition. The tariffs, however, are directly affecting his own companies’ bottom lines. Dozens of major businesses across multiple sectors have warned in their first-quarter earnings reports of the impact they will suffer from Trump’s new trade policy.

The blow to companies’ earnings and profits comes primarily through two channels: the direct effect on businesses with a global supply chain that import goods from countries subject to the new tariffs, and the effect of uncertainty and loss of confidence, which translates into a slowdown in consumer spending and the economy in general.

Berkshire Hathaway warned of the “considerable uncertainty” introduced by the trade war. The group, a conglomerate with companies in numerous sectors, warned in its quarterly report of the potential impact through changes in product costs, supply chain efficiency, and customer demand for its products and services. Around three out of four companies have alluded to the tariffs in their earnings reports.

General Motors warned of a $4 billion to $5 billion impact on its financials this year. The company lowered its adjusted earnings before interest and tax from a previous range of $11.2 billion to $12.5 billion, down to $8.2 billion to $10.1 billion. Ford suspended its annual financial guidance on Monday due to tariff-related uncertainty, after admitting a $1.5 billion impact on earnings, despite taking steps to mitigate an additional $1 billion.

Apple estimated that the impact of the current measures would still result in an additional cost of approximately $900 million in the second quarter. CEO Tim Cook hinted that the impact could be greater in subsequent quarters.

Amazon stated that its future results could be affected by “tariff and trade policies.” Andy Jassy, president and CEO, said on a call with analysts, “It’s hard to tell what’s going to happen with tariffs right now. It’s hard to tell where they’re going to settle and when they’re going to settle.”

Colgate-Palmolive estimates that the tariffs will cause $200 million in increased costs. Procter & Gamble indicated that it is even considering reformulating its products to try to mitigate the cost increases (and price increases) resulting from the new tariffs, while lowering its sales forecast to between $1.7 billion and $3.4 billion for the year. Clorox also lowered its growth forecast on Monday.

PepsiCo lowered its full-year adjusted profit forecast due to uncertainty, rising supply chain costs, and signs of weakening consumer sentiment. McDonald’s has already suffered its biggest drop in sales since the pandemic in the first quarter.

Airbnb and Booking.com cited increased economic uncertainty when they released forecasts that disappointed the market. American Airlines and Delta Air Lines have withdrawn their 2025 forecasts, citing uncertainty stemming from Trump’s trade policies, while Southwest Airlines and United Airlines are halting their growth plans in anticipation of lower demand for domestic leisure travel.

The head of steelmaker Nucor, Leon Topalian, expressed optimism about demand following the 25% tariffs imposed on aluminum and steel from his foreign competitors.

title: Effects of Trump’s trade war loom over the Port of Virginia
content: Based on 2021 data, the Port of Virginia accounts for $153 billion added to the United State economy, supports 1.29 million jobs and employs about 565,000 people in Virginia.
resumen:
The Port of Virginia supports 1.29 million jobs, employs 565,000 people in Virginia and accounts for over $100 billion added to the national economy, 2021 data says.

Local experts and officials don’t have a clear picture of how the Trump administration’s tariff policy will affect the Port of Virginia and the many thousands of jobs connected to it, but ports across the country are bracing for a significant slowdown in traffic.

Impacts will be felt between May and July, according to Vinod Agarwal, a professor of economics at Old Dominion University and deputy director for ODU’s Dragas Center for Economic Analysis and Policy.

The tariffs are levied on “just about every trade lane we have,” said Joe Harris, a spokesperson for the Port of Virginia.

Port of Virginia CEO Stephen Edwards said, “very plainly, it’s hard to know.”

The port had its second-busiest March on record, according to Harris.

Agarwal said is “simply because everyone knew the tariffs would be taking place in April and if you’re in the business of importing goods you want to make sure they arrive in time before the tariffs go into effect.”

Tariffs should lead to a decrease in imports at almost all U.S. ports, not just the Port of Virginia, according to Agarwal.

The effect of the tariffs has not yet been seen in as much detail as is likely to be seen in the next couple of months.

The tariffs will lead to increases in prices, the higher prices will result in decreased demand for these products, so we should see a decline in imports which will of course affect the Port of Virginia, according to Agarwal.

Based on 2021 data, the Port of Virginia accounts for $153 billion added to the United States economy, supports 1.29 million jobs and employs about 565,000 people in Virginia.

Gene Seroka, executive director of the Port of Los Angeles, which had an economic impact of $311 billion in 2021, said they’ve seen roughly 33% drop off in their import volume over the last few weeks.

Apollo Global Management estimates U.S. consumers could start seeing shortages on store shelves by mid- to late-May, that there will be layoffs in the trucking and retail industries in late May and early June, and that there will be a recession by this summer.

title: US, Chinese officials to hold trade talks in Switzerland
content: Senior US and Chinese officials will travel to Switzerland later this week to kickstart stalled trade talks following President Donald Trump’s sweeping tar ...
resumen: Senior US and Chinese officials will meet in Switzerland to restart stalled trade talks. The talks aim to de-escalate the trade war intensified by President Donald Trump’s tariffs. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Vice Premier He Lifeng will lead the negotiations. Senior US and Chinese officials will travel to Switzerland later this week to kickstart stalled trade talks following President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariff rollout. The talks mark the first official public engagement between the world’s two largest economies aimed at resolving a trade war escalated by Trump shortly after his return to office in January. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and US Trade Representative (USTR) Jamieson Greer will attend the talks on behalf of the United States. Bessent told Fox News that the sides would hold meetings on Saturday and Sunday, local time. Vice Premier He Lifeng will attend for Beijing, China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced. The USTR announced that Greer would also meet with “his counterpart from the People’s Republic of China to discuss trade matters”, without naming He. Since Trump returned to the White House in January, his administration has levied new tariffs that now total 145% on goods from China. Beijing retaliated by slapping 125 levies on US imports to China. The tit-for-tat tariffs have left the two nations with cripplingly high levies. Bessent said that 145%, 125% is the equivalent of an embargo.

title: China Cuts Bank Reserve Ratio to Inject $138B Amid US Trade War
content: Chinas central bank has announced its first reserve requirement ratio (RRR) cut of 2025 to bolster the economy amid intensifying trade tensions with the United States. Peoples Bank of China (PBOC) ...
resumen: China’s central bank announced its first reserve requirement ratio (RRR) cut of 2025 to bolster the economy amid intensifying trade tensions with the United States. People's Bank of China (PBOC) Governor Pan Gongsheng said Wednesday the RRR will be lowered by 50 basis points, a move expected to inject approximately 1 trillion yuan ($138 billion) in liquidity into the financial system. The decision comes as China faces mounting economic pressure following U.S. President Donald Trump’s latest round of aggressive tariffs on Chinese goods. Beijing is stepping up monetary support to stabilize growth and ease credit conditions for businesses. The PBOC's action aligns with earlier commitments made at a key government meeting in late April, where Chinese officials pledged to adjust the RRR “in a timely manner” to counter external challenges and stimulate domestic demand. The liquidity boost is aimed at enhancing banks’ lending capacity, supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, and maintaining overall financial stability. Policymakers have been cautious about aggressive stimulus, opting instead for targeted tools like RRR adjustments to fine-tune monetary conditions. This move also reflects broader efforts by Chinese authorities to manage the fallout from the ongoing U.S.-China trade war. The PBOC’s latest intervention underscores China’s commitment to sustaining growth amid external shocks, with liquidity support emerging as a key lever in its economic strategy.

title: Asian stocks, dollar rise on China-US trade talks
content: Asian stocks rose at the open, and the dollar strengthened on confirmation that the US and China will hold dialogue, spurring optimism that trade tensions between the world’s two largest economies ...
resumen: Asian stocks rose at the open, and the dollar strengthened on confirmation that the US and China will hold dialogue, spurring optimism that trade tensions between the world’s two largest economies will ease. A gauge of regional equities gained, while index futures for the S&P 500 rose 0.8% on news that Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Trade Representative Jamieson Greer will meet with the Chinese government this week in Switzerland. The Australian dollar edged higher, while gold and Treasuries fell. The meeting will be first confirmed trade talks between the countries since President Donald Trump announced sweeping tariffs last month, led by punishing levies on China. Financial markets had gyrated on concerns that Trump ratcheting up his global trade war by imposing the highest levies in a century, and Beijing retaliating – will push the global economy into a recession. Trump placed duties as high as 145% on many Chinese imports, and Beijing retaliated with import taxes of 125% on American goods. The S&P 500 closed down 0.8% on Tuesday after Trump said he would prescribe tariff levels and concessions for partners looking to avoid higher duties. In Asia, China’s central bank and financial regulators will hold a press briefing at 9 am in Beijing to discuss policies aimed at stabilising markets. Investors are also focused on Wednesday’s rate decision by the Federal Reserve.

title: Can India navigate US-China trade tensions to boost green economy growth?
content: Reliance on Chinese inputs and shifting global trade rules could complicate India’s efforts to reach its climate targets, analysts warn.
resumen:
India está navegando una línea fina entre China y Estados Unidos mientras se apresura a hacer crecer su economía verde, con analistas advirtiendo que su dependencia de los insumos chinos y el cambio de las reglas comerciales globales podrían complicar sus esfuerzos para convertirse en un centro de tecnología limpia.

Si bien las recientes medidas arancelarias de Estados Unidos pueden ofrecer ganancias a corto plazo para los exportadores indios, Nueva Delhi sigue dependiendo en gran medida de China para componentes críticos, particularmente en el sector de la energía limpia, donde Beijing lidera tanto en producción como en innovación, advirtieron los analistas.

"No va a ser fácil para nosotros competir con China. Por ejemplo, si bien los titulares sugieren que Estados Unidos ahora importará más iPhones de India que de China, en realidad, India solo los está ensamblando. Los componentes aún provienen de China", dijo Aruna Sharma, ex secretaria del Ministerio de Acero de India.

Sus comentarios se produjeron durante un seminario web celebrado el lunes titulado "Qué significa la reorganización del comercio global para los objetivos de India para 2030", donde los analistas examinaron cómo la dinámica global cambiante podría afectar la estrategia económica de India en los próximos años.

Se espera que India, Japón y Corea del Sur se encuentren entre los primeros países con los que Estados Unidos podría firmar un acuerdo comercial, lo que podría ayudarlos a evitar los fuertes aranceles de importación de Washington sobre una serie de países que se anunciaron el mes pasado.

La nación del sur de Asia tiene la oportunidad de impulsar su industria manufacturera, incluidas las industrias verdes, pero necesitará introducir políticas para apoyar a sus pequeñas y medianas industrias que forman la mayor parte de su industria para cumplir las ambiciones de India a largo plazo, según Sharma.

title: Empresarios chinos alertan que aranceles de Trump encarecerán la construcción de viviendas en Estados Unidos
content: Desde clavos hasta paneles de yeso, los aranceles productos hechos en China están encareciendo el sueño de la casa propia para familias estadounidenses, de acuerdo con empresarios chinos del área de l ...
resumen:
Los aranceles impuestos por Trump a productos chinos en EE. UU. han elevado los costos de construcción de viviendas en más de 10.900 dólares por hogar, afectando a miles de familias estadounidenses.
La cadena de suministro entre China y EE. UU., fundamental para el sector inmobiliario, está bajo presión por los aranceles del 145% impuestos a productos provenientes del gigante asiático.
Estos impuestos amenazan con paralizar proyectos de construcción residencial en Estados Unidos debido al encarecimiento de artículos esenciales como tornillos, iluminación LED y contrachapado.
Los proveedores chinos afirman que, a pesar de los aranceles, sus productos aún son los preferidos por los constructores estadounidenses debido a su calidad y disponibilidad inmediata.
Ye Wen, empresario de Guangdong, destacó que los productos “Hechos en China” como tornillos, sujetadores, paneles decorativos y luces LED representan hasta el 50% del mercado estadounidense.
Los empresarios consultados aseguran que no están dispuestos a absorber los aranceles y que buscan otros mercados como Europa y la ASEAN para evitar pérdidas.
El 7% de los materiales usados en la construcción residencial proviene del extranjero, del cual China es uno de los principales proveedores.
Zhong Shangtian, empresario del sector, explicó que “bloquear productos chinos es eliminar una opción rentable para los desarrolladores”.
Algunos constructores ya optan por frenar sus proyectos, ante la incertidumbre y el encarecimiento de insumos básicos.

title: ‘Bai lan’ and how Trump’s tariffs are hurting China and helping the US
content: The objective of Trump's tariffs was to facilitate much-needed change and slowly but surely start to wean America's economy off its dependence on Beijing.
resumen: “Bai lan” is a Chinese colloquial expression that means “let it rot” or “let it decay.” In contemporary terms, it represents a phenomenon in China’s culture that describes an apathetic mindset and disposition to accept a deteriorating situation rather than engage in any effort to improve it. It’s analogous to the effects Trump’s tariffs can have on China. President Donald Trump started his political ambitions with a simple declaration: Make America great again. Over his presidential terms, this included confronting China on various economic issues, mainly concentrating on how the country has exploited the United States and our country’s (remaining) manufacturing capabilities and supply chain troubles for years. Trump’s tariffs on trade with China have caused geopolitical uncertainty worldwide. The objective of these tariffs was to facilitate much-needed change in the economic world order and slowly but surely start to wean America’s economy off its dependence on Beijing. This required strategic, long-term thinking that would benefit the country’s workforce and return manufacturing jobs to the country. This process began on “Liberation Day,” April 2, 2025. Trump’s tariff plans and disruption of the China supply chain racket unexpectedly threw a wrench into China’s plans. One of the fallouts of the COVID-19 pandemic was the startling realization that the U.S. was far too dependent on China. Trump is hellbent on trying to change this reality. Trump’s efforts are predicated on a course correction before the U.S. experiences “bai lan” or worse, suffers a fate similar to Rome in 410 A.D. and the Roman Empire in the fifth century. The little secret that liberals, Democrats, left-wingers, and their accomplices in the legacy media will not reveal is that Trump’s tariffs are hurting an already weakened Chinese economy. China is currently experiencing deflation. The unemployment rate is about 5%, with youth unemployment at a staggering 16.9% as of February 2025 (nearly twice the U.S. rate of 9.4%). Goldman Sachs cut China’s GDP forecast to 4% in 2025, and Citi analysts also cut China’s growth to about 4.2%. According to CNBC, the fallout in China from Trump’s tariffs “threatens to drive the world’s second-largest economy into deeper deflation.” Trump’s tariffs have hurt Chinese companies’ profitability due to the “recent influx of discounted goods” that were supposed to be shipped to the U.S. This could also significantly affect China’s unemployment rate in the future. The economic uncertainty over job prospects in the Chinese economy, related to the tariffs, has contributed to “weak consumer demand.” “After hovering just above zero in 2023 and 2024, the consumer price index slipped into negative territory, declining for two consecutive months in February and March,” noted CNBC. This is on top of the producer price index in China, which declined for the 29th consecutive month. The 2.5% drop experienced in March, compared to last year, was “its steepest decline in four months” — arguably a correlation to Trump’s tariffs. Adding to China’s woes are the possibility of Chinese stocks being delisted from American stock exchanges and recent trade negotiations between the U.S. and countries such as India and Italy.

title: After Trump tariffs, Malaysia delays local hikes in bid to fuel economic growth
content: Softening RON95, electricity and SST increases will deepen the fiscal deficit but shore up a slowing economy. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen: Malaysia is set to take a hit to its coffers due to the US import tariff regime. Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is postponing measures such as tax hikes and subsidy cuts. Higher sales and services tax (SST) rates on a broader basket of items were due to be implemented on May 1, but the expansion has been postponed. A plan to cut subsidies for base-level RON95 petrol, initially scheduled for June, is set to be delayed or watered down. A minister admitted that it is "very difficult" to cut fuel subsidies now. A 24 per cent tariff against Malaysia was announced on April 2, with a 90-day pause put into effect. Datuk Seri Anwar said during a special May 5 parliamentary sitting that "there is a possibility that the US will reduce the reciprocal tariffs imposed on Malaysia" if ongoing negotiations are successful. The Budget 2025 projection for GDP growth in 2025, between 4.5 per cent and 5.5 per cent, may be revised. An electricity price hike of 14 per cent in July is expected. The government is under pressure to further subsidise the cost of the key utility beyond the RM6 billion allocated for the first half of 2025. Opposition leader Hamzah Zainudin urged the Anwar administration “to delay raising the price for RON95”. The SST expansion, which was set to rake in RM5 billion for the Treasury in 2025, is now due to be gazetted on June 1. Sources involved in stakeholder engagements told ST that more than 4,000 new items are expected to be hit by the tax. The inflationary impact from businesses passing on SST and electricity hikes to customers would also be compounded by a RON95 price increase. Abolishing diesel subsidies at petrol stations curbed 6.5 million litres of smuggled diesel daily. Annual savings from the measure are set to come up to RM7.5 billion. Oil prices have dropped from US$75 a barrel and dipping below US$60 on May 5. A per barrel price of US$55 could see RON95 costs match the RM2.05 tag at the pump. Budget 2025 had pencilled in a fiscal deficit of 3.8 per cent of GDP. The government’s advance estimate for the first quarter was a lower-than-expected 4.4 per cent.

title: A Message from the Market
content: When US president Donald Trump detonated a trade bomb on 2nd April, with levies set to bite from 9th April, global markets shuddered. Stocks tumbled for four days as investors braced for chaos. Yet, ...
resumen: When US president Donald Trump detonated a trade bomb on 2nd April, with levies set to bite from 9th April, global markets shuddered. Stocks tumbled for four days as investors braced for chaos. Yet, days later, president Trump paused the tariffs for 90 days on all—excluding China—and exempted electronics, triggering a relief rally. The German market has hit a lifetime high. The S&P500 has recorded nine consecutive days of positive closing, its longest winning streak in 20 years, and on Friday, it closed at 5,686—above its pre-tariff level. The Indian market climbed 3.5% in April. Yale University’s Budget Lab estimates the 2025 tariffs will lift US consumer prices by 2.3%, costing households US$3,800 annually (in 2024 dollars). Car prices could rise by US$2,000–US$10,000, iPhones by 40%, and groceries will not be spared. The IMF, citing the tariffs, slashed its 2025 US growth forecast from 2.7% to 1.8% and pegged the global recession risk at 60%, up from 40%. US GDP growth may shrink by 0.9 percentage points in 2025. The US Consumers’ Expectations Index dropped 12.5 points to 54.4, the lowest level since October 2011. The obvious initial driver of market gains has been president Trump’s 90-day pause on ‘reciprocal’ tariffs for most countries, excluding China. This sparked a massive market rally, with the S&P 500 soaring 9.5%—its third-best day since 1940—and the Nasdaq jumping 12.2%. Investors now appear to be wagering that this trade war, too, will end in an eleventh-hour compromise. While institutions have sold off through April, retail investors have been buying the dip. April saw 177,000 new jobs, and inflation cooled to 2.4% in March, below forecasts of 2.6%. In India, a weakening dollar against the rupee lured foreign investors back, while domestic funds, now outstripping their foreign counterparts in holdings, kept buying. Over 200 lawsuits have been filed challenging a range of executive actions, with 70 federal rulings—on issues from immigration to federal spending—thwarting his plans. The Supreme Court has already blocked deportations under the Alien Enemies Act, and Mr Trump’s use of the 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act to impose tariffs may yet be struck down as illegal.

title: Bajan del 75 % al 63 % las empresas españolas que aumentarán inversiones en Latinoamérica
content: Madrid, 6 may (EFE).- Un 63 % de empresas españolas aumentarán sus inversiones en Latinoamérica este año, con un descenso "significativo" en comparación con los últimos años, cuando la cifra solía ron ...
resumen:
Un 63 % de empresas españolas aumentarán sus inversiones en Latinoamérica este año, con un descenso "significativo" en comparación con los últimos años, cuando la cifra solía rondar el 75 %, según el informe anual 'Panorama de Inversión Española en Iberoamérica 2025', de IE University.
Otro 30 %. de las empresas española prevé mantener sus inversiones en Latinoamérica y el 7 % las disminuirán.
En el caso de las empresas pequeñas y medianas (pymes), solo la mitad considera aumentar su apuesta por la región, un descenso "brusco" respecto al 80 % de años anteriores.
México será el país más "afectado económicamente" por su alta exposición a Estados Unidos, pero volverá a ser donde más empresas españolas aumentarán sus inversiones, seguido por Colombia, y Chile, Perú y Brasil. También subirán en Costa Rica y Paraguay, y se mantendrán en el resto en general.
Respecto a Argentina, y a pesar de sus "enormes dificultades", las empresas españolas creen que será el país con un mejor desempeño económico en 2025 en la zona, seguida por Uruguay y República Dominicana. Cierran Venezuela, Cuba y Nicaragua.
Por primera vez, no será Iberoamérica (64 %), sino la Unión Europea (71 %) el mercado en el que más empresas españolas prevén subir sus ventas en ese plazo.
La volatilidad cambiaria es, este año, "el aspecto que más afectará a las ventas y negocios de las empresas españolas, por encima de la inestabilidad jurídica y de la inflación, según la encuesta.
El atractivo de los mercados internos vuelve a ser la mayor ventaja que encuentra para invertir (67 %), seguida por la mano de obra cualificada.
Entre las amenazas percibidas, destacan la inestabilidad política (76 %) y el ya mencionado riesgo cambiario (56 %).
