title: El sol peruano sigue brillando a pesar de las presiones globales, pero volatilidad podría hacernos ‘sombra’
content: Análisis del tipo de cambio. Con fuertes y prontas alzas y bajas ha estado el dólar en Perú en los últimos meses. ¿Cuál es el tipo de cambio que se proyecta para 2025?
resumen: El sol peruano mantiene un buen desempeño frente al dólar a pesar de las presiones globales, aunque se espera un periodo de volatilidad a corto plazo. El tipo de cambio cerró a S/3,6510 el 2 de mayo, después de varios cierres a la baja, tras el anuncio de aranceles del 10% a Perú por parte de la administración de Donald Trump. Benoit Mougenot, de la USIL, señala que el dólar ha caído frente al sol y al euro (10%). Eduardo Jiménez, de Macroconsult, indica que el sol peruano está atrayendo capitales debido a los movimientos en Estados Unidos. Macroconsult y Credicorp Capital coinciden en que la volatilidad continuará en los próximos meses. Credicorp Capital sugiere cautela debido a la guerra comercial y la posibilidad de una recesión global, lo que podría afectar el precio del cobre. Jiménez destaca que la volatilidad en Perú es menor en comparación con otros países de la región debido a la intervención del Banco Central de Reserva (BCRP). Jiménez proyecta que el tipo de cambio estará en S/3,73. Credicorp Capital afirma que los desarrollos políticos impactarán en el sol peruano en el segundo semestre de 2025. Credicorp Capital señala que las elecciones de 2026 serán clave para la estabilidad política y social. Credicorp Capital ve que la incertidumbre y los riesgos permanecen elevados, especialmente con el posible octavo retiro de AFP. Macroconsult ve una probabilidad media baja de aprobación del retiro de AFP. Se proyecta que el valor del dólar suba por encima de S/3,70 hacia fines de año. Macroconsult estima que un posible octavo retiro de AFP podría alcanzar los S/28 millones, frente a los S/27 millones 258 mil del 2024. Las expectativas empresariales son optimistas. Credicorp Capital resalta que el PEN continuaría destacándose en la región a mediano plazo. Benoit Mougenot resalta la comunicación del BCRP, que sugiere mantener la calma. El Perú tiene US$ 85 billones de dólares en reservas no dólares, una de las más importantes de la región. La dolarización de la economía peruana es baja, con un 23% actualmente. Credicorp Capital proyecta el USDPEN en S/3,75 para diciembre de 2025. Macroconsult ve un promedio del tipo de cambio en S/3,71 para 2025, y proyecta que cerrará en S/3,73.

title: Democrats Have Been at War With Oil for Too Long
content: Democrats have missed opportunities to stabilize the oil market in the past. When oil prices crashed during the Covid pandemic, threatening shale companies with bankruptcy, party leaders blocked a ...
resumen:
It’s been a brutal three months for the American oil and gas industry. Oil prices have dropped to their lowest level since 2021, below what most shale companies need for new drilling to be profitable. China recently halted imports of American liquefied natural gas in the latest act of trade retaliation. And as the Trump administration’s tariffs on Mexico and Canada hit materials and equipment, the cost of producing oil and gas in America is rising.

OPEC, the International Energy Agency and Goldman Sachs have all forecast softer oil demand in anticipation of a global economic downturn set off by President Trump’s trade war. The chaos has even eclipsed any gains from Mr. Trump's industry-friendly regulatory rollbacks and efforts to fast-track approvals for new energy projects. As one industry veteran put it in a recent Dallas Federal Reserve survey of oil and gas executives, “I have never felt more uncertainty about our business in my entire 40-plus-year career.” And this turmoil is no accident; it’s a direct result of Mr. Trump’s economic vandalism.

A weakened American oil and gas industry hands more power to OPEC, leaving U.S. households vulnerable the next time it cuts production and drives up prices. That means American consumers could eventually feel pain at the pump.

Democrats would be wise to underscore this uncertainty to voters, who want secure prices and energy. Stable energy prices depend on stable policy — and this moment calls for a Democratic agenda that prioritizes both.

When oil prices crashed during the Covid pandemic, threatening shale companies with bankruptcy, party leaders blocked a plan championed by Texas and Oklahoma Democrats to buy oil for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

By 2021, as oil demand rebounded with the economy, U.S. shale producers were ill equipped to ramp up production and counter OPEC’s production restraint or the looming shock from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Ultimately, U.S. consumers paid the price to the tune of $5 a gallon of gasoline. Alongside missteps like these, Democrats’ political gestures like fracking bans have alienated an industry that has helped reduce America’s reliance on oil from countries such as Saudi Arabia and Russia.

Democrats have a tricky line to walk, balancing climate priorities and energy security. But they can chart a new course if they stop treating domestic oil and gas production as a liability.

This doesn’t mean adopting a mindless “drill, baby, drill” mentality; it’s about recognizing that domestic oil and gas companies deliver geopolitical value and economic benefits by keeping the world less reliant on Russia and OPEC. The industry can also help accelerate decarbonization with innovation and financial might.

And admitting this doesn’t have to be at odds with Democrats’ efforts to enforce strong pollution standards and hold bad oil and gas actors accountable. To unlock production across the energy system, stability is crucial to provide a reliable investment environment and clear rules of the road.

An obvious place for Democrats to pursue this is in a robust defense of the Inflation Reduction Act. The sweeping Biden-era law is diversifying and expanding the American energy system. Without that additional supply, volatility is inevitable.

Republicans are now pushing to repeal up to $400 billion worth of the law’s energy tax credits — a move that would stall energy investment and drive consumer prices still higher. That will give Democrats the chance to make the case that diverse energy sources are the best hedge against price spikes in any single fuel.

While Mr. Trump kneecaps American oil and gas with tariffs and by encouraging OPEC to produce more, Democrats can instead offer a plan to refill the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. That will help U.S. producers survive a price crash driven by OPEC oversupply while protecting consumers from future supply shocks.

Achieving stability also means fixing outdated permitting laws that stifle energy development of all kinds and undermine the government’s ability to invest in it. While Democrats in Congress may not be able to pass legislation without a majority, it is time for them to offer a platform that reduces the uncertainty that paralyzes the infrastructure critical to achieving climate goals and energy reliability.

Mr. Trump can wrap chaos in bravado, but his policies have already hurt American producers and undermined our economy. Ultimately they will also hurt consumers.

Democrats can make that plain. They can be the party of reliable energy, robust domestic production and decarbonization — but only if they embrace an agenda that responds to the complexity of the moment with steadiness.

title: The USMCA Strategic Initiative: Understanding the Future of North American Trade
content: The USMCA Strategic Initiative is anchored by a series of invitation-only roundtables convening government officials, trade experts, and private sector leaders from all three countries to discuss ...
resumen:
The USMCA Strategic Initiative is anchored by a series of invitation-only roundtables convening government officials, trade experts, and private sector leaders from all three countries to discuss challenges and opportunities ahead of the mandatory 2026 USMCA review process.

The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) is the cornerstone of North American trade. It is estimated that $3 million dollars in products move across the U.S.-Mexico and U.S.-Canada borders every minute. The United States, Mexico, and Canada have the potential to build a secure, dynamic, and globally competitive North America amid a world of burgeoning geopolitical competition.

In the four years since the agreement entered into force, the USMCA has demonstrated resilience. The USMCA continues to play a critical role in catalyzing prosperity, integration, and cooperation among the three countries.

CSIS’ USMCA Strategic Initiative’s activities will be anchored by a series of invitation-only roundtables, which will convene government officials, trade experts, private sector leaders, academics and think tank scholars from all three countries to discuss challenges and opportunities ahead of the mandatory 2026 USMCA review process.

Topics discussed as part of this project include: nearshoring, industrial policy, and supply chain relocation; regional economic security; trade imbalances and the prospect of tariffs; labor and environmental standards; North American competitiveness; intellectual property rights; creating the North American corridor and North America as a strategic concept; digital trade and e-commerce; automotive sector; and food and agriculture.

This project is made possible through generous support from the Corn Refiners Association, CPKC, General Motors, Mitsui, Rassini, Scotiabank and Vulcan Materials.

Rubi Bledsoe is the Research Associate, Americas Program.

title: A un mes de los aranceles de Trump: ¿Cuál ha sido el impacto en las fábricas globales?
content: Publicaciones a principios de semana revelaron daños en los dos principales combatientes, cuyos aranceles han eliminado los incentivos para el comercio entre países que representan más del 40 por cien ...
resumen:
Los informes asiáticos del viernes fueron desalentadores: Corea del Sur y Taiwán cayeron drásticamente.
Es poco probable que la confianza de las fábricas mejore hasta que haya claridad sobre hacia dónde se dirigen los aranceles.
Esta semana surgieron más señales en una ola de informes que indican que la manufactura global está cediendo ante la guerra comercial del presidente Donald Trump.
Los índices de gerentes de compras en Asia, junto con los números revisados ​​en Europa el viernes, mostraron contracciones nuevas o persistentes en la actividad fabril en abril.
Pocas economías están evitando la conmoción de los aranceles y la incertidumbre paralizante que ha envuelto a la economía mundial un mes después de que el presidente de Estados Unidos anunciara impuestos generalizados a las importaciones estadounidenses.
Un informe publicado el jueves mostró que la actividad manufacturera estadounidense registró su mayor contracción en cinco meses, un día después de que datos revelaran que las fábricas chinas sufrieron la contracción más profunda desde diciembre de 2023.
Es poco probable que la confianza de las fábricas mejore hasta que haya claridad sobre hacia dónde se dirigen los aranceles, lo que puede llevar tiempo, dijo James Knightley, economista internacional jefe de ING.
“La naturaleza intermitente de los aranceles está generando una enorme incertidumbre, lo que lleva a las empresas a cruzarse de brazos”, dijo Knightley. “No tomarán decisiones importantes hasta tener la certeza de que no habrá otro cambio inmediato en el entorno económico”.
La directora ejecutiva del Fondo Monetario Internacional, Kristalina Georgieva, advirtió que las probabilidades de una recesión mundial aumentarán si persiste la incertidumbre.
Los índices de los gigantes manufactureros de la región, como Corea del Sur y Taiwán, cayeron drásticamente ante la caída de los pedidos y los recortes de producción, según S&P Global.
En el Sudeste Asiático, la actividad se contrajo en Tailandia, Malasia e Indonesia.
India fue un caso excepcional, con una expansión de su actividad.
El índice manufacturero S&P Global alcanzó su máximo en 32 meses en la eurozona.
“La actividad industrial sigue estando muy expuesta a la política arancelaria estadounidense”, declaró Cyrus de la Rubia, economista jefe del Hamburg Commercial Bank.
“Los fabricantes lograron ampliar claramente sus márgenes de beneficio en abril, ya que los precios de compra cayeron, mientras que los de venta subieron a su ritmo más rápido en dos años”.
Cyrus de la Rubia añadió que cualquier mejora podría ser efímera dada la desviación comercial que están causando los aranceles.
Mohit Kumar, economista jefe para Europa de Jefferies International, advirtió que las cifras del PMI hasta el momento son sólo el comienzo y que el impacto puede persistir a pesar de cualquier acuerdo comercial que concluya Trump.
Las cifras publicadas el viernes mostraron que el índice JPMorgan Global Manufacturing de producción futura disminuyó en abril al nivel más bajo desde octubre de 2022.
En Sudáfrica, los fabricantes se mostraron más pesimistas.
El índice de gerentes de compras (PMI) de Absa Group Ltd., elaborado por la Oficina de Investigación Económica, cayó a 44,7 en abril.
El sector manufacturero de Brasil estuvo cerca del estancamiento en abril, con el PMI cayendo a 50,3, el nivel más débil desde diciembre de 2023.
En México, el PMI cayó a 44.8 en abril desde 46.5 en marzo, marcando su décimo mes consecutivo de contracción y la lectura más baja desde febrero de 2021.
Gene Seroka, director ejecutivo del Puerto de Los Ángeles, dijo que ve semanas o meses de interrupciones tanto para los minoristas como para las fábricas estadounidenses, dado el tiempo que les toma a las empresas redirigir sus cadenas de suministro para evitar los aranceles del 145 por ciento de Estados Unidos sobre la mayoría de los productos chinos.

title: A Tidal Wave of Change Is Headed for the U.S. Economy
content: Steep tariffs on Chinese imports are set to ripple through the U.S. economy, potentially leading to higher prices and empty shelves.
resumen: More companies are starting to warn that they will have to pass on higher costs to American consumers, raising prices for products like strollers, mattresses, power tools and cast-iron cookware as the Trump administration’s tariffs take hold. President Trump's tariffs on Chinese goods have drastically slowed trade, impacting container ship traffic across the Pacific. Experts predict consumers will soon face higher prices and product shortages as the effects of tariffs intensify. Disruptions at ports and falling truck sales signal potential economic downturn and recession risks for summer 2025. When the COVID pandemic hit, factories in China shut down and global shipping traffic slowed. A similar trend is beginning to play out, but this time the catalyst is President Donald Trump’s decision to raise tariffs on Chinese imports to a minimum of 145%, an amount so steep that much of the trade between the United States and China has ground to a halt. Fewer massive container ships have been plying the ocean between Chinese and American ports, and in the coming weeks, far fewer Chinese goods will arrive on American shores. The number of massive container ships carrying metal boxes of toys, furniture and other products departing China for the United States plummeted by about one-third in April. It takes 20 to 40 days for a container ship to travel across the Pacific Ocean. It then takes another one to 10 days for Chinese goods to make their way by train or truck to various cities around the country. By late May or early June, consumers could start to see some empty shelves, and layoffs could occur for retailers and logistics industries. The major effects on the U.S. economy of shutting down trade with China will start to become apparent in the summer of 2025, when the United States might slip into a recession, said Torsten Slok, an economist at Apollo. U.S. consumers will within a few weeks see empty shelves in clothing stores, toy stores, hardware stores and retail drugstores, and higher prices of the goods that still are on the shelves. Molson Hart, CEO of Viahart, a toy company, wrote on the social platform X: “It’s almost like we’re speeding towards a brick wall but the driver of the car doesn’t see it yet. By the time he does, it’ll be too late to hit the brakes.” The decline in Chinese imports was amplified Friday, when the United States eliminated so-called de minimis treatment for Chinese goods. The rule had allowed products up to $800 to avoid tariffs as long as they are shipped directly to consumers. The decision to get rid of it is already resulting in higher prices for U.S. consumers. The change is expected to weigh on airlines and private carriers like FedEx. At the port of Los Angeles, the main entry point for Chinese products arriving in the United States, imports surged in recent months as businesses and consumers tried to stock up on goods in advance of the tariffs coming into effect. The number of containers arriving at the Port of Los Angeles is expected to drop more than 35% this coming week compared with the same period last year, port data shows. Gene Seroka, the port’s executive director, said that a quarter of the ships that had been scheduled for May had canceled because of light volume. Data shows that sales of heavy trucks have fallen sharply, too, suggesting that companies in the logistics space expect to be moving fewer goods in the future. Trade experts say that companies have stockpiled enough inventory in recent months that, if the White House reverses course soon and significantly drops tariffs on China, much of the pain for the U.S. economy and consumers can be avoided. Data from the Institute for Supply Management shows that U.S. inventories are at their highest level in more than two years. Gabriel Wildau, a managing director at Teneo, who advises companies on doing business with China, said that the Chinese goods that U.S. retailers had stockpiled in the first three months of the year would give stores some time before they would need to raise prices. American consumers will feel the impact of trade changes unfold over the next three to six months. We’re going to have higher prices and, in some cases, empty shelves. Trump officials have admitted that there could be some disruptions for consumers. The president seemed to acknowledge Wednesday that his trade changes could lead to fewer goods and higher prices. At a White House briefing Tuesday, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said that he did not expect to see supply chain shocks from U.S. tariffs on China. Some firms that are in a more fragile financial position have not been able to stockpile and are rapidly being forced out of business. Many companies say that tariffs above 50% on Chinese imports are enough to stop trade entirely. With tariffs now at a minimum of 145%, and in some cases much higher, that would mean that the Trump administration may have to drop its China tariffs by at least 100 percentage points to meaningfully restart the flow of goods. Ryan Petersen, CEO of Flexport, a supply chain company, said that, even before the president hiked tariffs on China to 145% in April, the tariffs the Trump administration had put on China were high, at a minimum of 54%. Data shows that new orders from manufacturers have turned down sharply this year, while companies have trimmed back their plans for capital expenditures. Some major companies have stopped issuing guidance for their sales and profits. Mercedes-Benz on Wednesday suspended its financial forecasts for 2025, as did Stellantis, which makes the Chrysler, Dodge and Jeep brands. During the pandemic, supply chains disruptions took much longer to work their way through the economy than most forecasters had anticipated. Economists who initially expected price increases to be transitory were surprised at inflationary pressures that lingered for years. Petersen said that companies that operated container ships had already canceled a quarter of all sailings to the United States from China, and they are rerouting their ships to travel to Southeast Asia and Europe instead.

title: Major US electric bike brand announces response to tariffs
content: One of the largest electric bike brands in the US, Aventon, has recently shared several details about the company’s ...
resumen:
Aventon, one of the largest electric bike brands in the US, shared details about the company’s response to US tariffs on imported goods.

Aventon covered the company’s response to supply chain disruptions, manufacturing shifts, and pricing policy.

As Trump’s threats to cripple US imports from China grew, Aventon began focusing on alternative manufacturing locations.

Other Southeast Asian countries like Vietnam, Cambodia, and Thailand are seen as prime locations to shift e-bike manufacturing outside of China.

Many of the new bicycle factories opened in these countries are actually Chinese-owned.

Moving manufacturing outside of China comes with increasing costs and complexities.

Critical parts (e.g., motors, batteries) still often come from China.

This multi-step process adds 50+ days to shipment times compared to direct manufacturing in China.

The current tariff on e-bikes from countries other than China sits at a minimum of 10%, but those could rise this summer after a 90-day pause granted by the Trump administration ends.

Tariffs are paid by importers during customs clearance before products reach the U.S. soil, and these costs typically trickle down to consumers through price adjustments.

Aventon has committed to keeping costs as low as possible by absorbing the increase in costs.

In early 2025, Aventon shifted 100% of its production to Thailand, increasing manufacturing and logistics costs by 10-15%.

Aventon intends to absorb the current price increases due to sensitivity to inflation in the US.

Aventon won’t be bringing production of its electric bikes to the US anytime soon, citing a lack of domestic supply for critical components and the heavy tariffs applied to those components.

The company doesn’t rule out the possibility for e-bike assembly to occur on a smaller scale if tariffs are lifted.

There is no supply chain of e-bike components here in the US and all key components are imposed with significant tariffs coming from China.

Having e-bikes made in the US is not practical unless the parts tariffs are lifted.

title: ‘Our Economy Is Spring-Loaded’: SBA Chief Loeffler Dismisses Tariff Fearmongering, Celebrates Jobs Report
content: Small Business Administration chief Kelly Loeffler says the U.S. economy is "spring-loaded" for a boom, downplaying fears about tariffs.
resumen:
Small Business Administrator Kelly Loeffler celebrated Friday’s jobs report, dismissed fears about a tariff-induced recession, and expressed optimism that the U.S. economy is “spring-loaded” for success.

Loeffler told The Daily Signal in an interview at the Job Creators Network’s Freedom Fighters Summit in Savannah on Friday.

Loeffler went over what her agency had achieved in the first 100 days of the administration: cutting climate activist and diversity lending programs in order to focus on merit; moving regional offices out of “sanctuary” cities that prevent law enforcement from reporting illegal aliens to federal authorities; and launching the “Made in America” manufacturing initiative across the states.

Loeffler called the coming years “really exciting,” mentioning Congress’ effort to preserve the Trump tax cuts, decreasing the size and scope of government, and bringing manufacturing back to the U.S.

She predicted companies bringing jobs back to the U.S., “driven by the fair-trade policy, and we’re already seeing it at work.”

“President Trump announced at the White House the other day $8 trillion in investments by big companies,” Loeffler noted.

Loeffler celebrated the Department of Labor’s April jobs report, released Friday. The report showed that employers added 177,000 jobs in April, above economists’ expectations. Employers added 167,000 private sector jobs, while state and local government job increases offset the decline of 9,000 jobs in the federal government, bringing the total to 10,000 new government jobs.

Loeffler, a former senator from Georgia, added that President Trump’s policies are working to rapidly reverse the pace of that decline.

She teased that Trump will be announcing new trade deals that “could never have been possible without the president’s strong belief in the American worker and in the American industrial base that is coming back rapidly—and if we can get the tax cuts done, our economy is spring-loaded.”

Loeffler highlighted Trump’s efforts on trade.

The SBA chief said, “I think the worst narrative is the incessant focus on tariffs, because we should be saying ‘fair trade’ instead of ‘tariffs.’”

“Let’s be very clear: Democrats are against fair trade and what fair trade is doing,” she declared.

title: Taiwán afirma haber concluido la primera ronda de negociaciones arancelarias con EEUU
content: El Gobierno taiwanés afirmó este sábado que había concluido la primera ronda de negociaciones con Estados Unidos sobre "aranceles recíprocos y otros temas económicos y comerciales", describiendo el am ...
resumen:
El Gobierno taiwanés afirmó este sábado que había concluido la primera ronda de negociaciones con Estados Unidos sobre “aranceles recíprocos y otros temas económicos y comerciales”, describiendo el ambiente de dichas reuniones como “franco y cordial”, informaron fuentes oficiales.

Las conversaciones, que concluyeron el jueves pasado en Washington, estuvieron centradas en aranceles, barreras comerciales no arancelarias y “diversas formas de cooperación económica y comercial entre Taiwán y Estados Unidos”.

Ambas partes expresaron su expectativa común de fortalecer la cooperación económica y comercial bilateral, y manifestaron su deseo de generar más oportunidades para el desarrollo industrial y económico de ambos países sobre la base del beneficio mutuo.

Asimismo, acordaron continuar las consultas en el corto plazo sobre los distintos temas, con el objetivo de buscar activamente consensos y explorar una cooperación más profunda.

La viceprimera ministra taiwanesa, Cheng Li-chiun, subrayó su confianza en que, mediante un “diálogo continuo, abierto y basado en el entendimiento mutuo”, se podrá “consolidar el mayor grado posible de consenso” entre ambas partes.

Esta reunión presencial tuvo lugar tres semanas después de que Taiwán y EEUU celebrasen una primera videoconferencia sobre los “aranceles recíprocos” anunciados el 2 de abril por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, contra los principales socios comerciales de Washington, y que en el caso de la isla ascendían al 32%.

El mandatario taiwanés, William Lai, propuso entablar negociaciones con EEUU sobre la premisa de ‘aranceles cero’, siguiendo el modelo del Tratado entre México, Estados Unidos y Canadá.

Taipéi “buscará reducir el desequilibrio comercial” con Washington mediante la adquisición de energía, productos agrícolas, bienes industriales y armamento, al tiempo que constató su intención de aumentar las inversiones en territorio estadounidense y “eliminar las barreras comerciales no arancelarias”.

Si esas líneas de negociación fracasan y EEUU impone gravámenes sobre los semiconductores —principal baza exportadora de la isla—, o reactiva sus “aranceles recíprocos”, el impacto sobre la economía taiwanesa sería notable.

El Gobierno ya admitió que tendría dificultades para crecer por encima del 3% este año si se concreta ese escenario.

title: Chicago's housing market could be further dampened by recession fears and tariffs
content: Tariffs are "very relevant" for the housing market, experts say, and could raise home prices as the local housing supply continues to shrink.
resumen:
Chicago's housing market could be further dampened by recession fears and tariffs. Tariffs are “very relevant” for the housing market, and could raise home prices as the local housing supply continues to shrink.

Evan Mast, an economics professor at the University of Notre Dame, thinks President Donald Trump’s tariffs and fears of a recession in the U.S. may add fuel to the fire.

Trump’s tariff policies have been central to his second term. Last month, he said he would place 10% “reciprocal” tariffs on most nations. But facing a global stock market meltdown, he issued a 90-day pause but raised tariffs on Chinese imports to 145%.

The tariffs affect goods including steel, clothing and semiconductors — causing higher prices for importers and ultimately, consumers. Experts say tariffs could also mean bad news for the housing market through higher material costs for homebuilders and possible interest rate spikes for consumers.

Redfin’s head of economic research, Chen Zhao, said the economic impact of this is very relevant for the housing market.

Chicago-based Lexington Homes has built more than 40,000 homes across the Chicago area since its founding in 1973. Lexington Homes Principal Jeff Benach said tariffs could largely be a “wait-and-see” situation.

Roughly 85% of all U.S. softwood lumber is imported from Canada, according to the National Association of Home Builders. The U.S. Department of Commerce said it was considering increasing lumber duties from its current 14.5% to 34.5%, with a final decision expected in August.

The National Association of Home Builders said last month it filed a letter with the Commerce Department arguing that additional lumber tariffs shouldn’t be imposed because housing is a critical component of national security.

Builders estimate tariffs will add $10,900 to the cost of a home, according to the association.

Homebuyers have been pummeled by interest rates that averaged as high as 7.22% last year. The average rate on a 30-year mortgage fell to 6.76% from 6.81% last week, Freddie Mac said Thursday. A 15-year fixed rate mortgage fell to 5.29% from 5.94% last week. It’s down from 6.47% a year ago, Freddie Mac said.

Tariffs impact interest rates in a few ways, Zhao said. They can lead to inflation, which could cause interest rates to rise. But tariffs can also have a recessionary impact if consumers pull back from spending because of higher prices, Zhao said. Depending on how tariffs impact the economy, it could influence the Federal Reserve to cut rates.

BluPrint Home Loans Senior Vice President Joey Rosen sees a window of opportunity for potential homebuyers.

Pekarsky said his team had a massive first quarter with 127 homes sold. During that same time last year, his team closed on 76 homes.

The median rent in Chicago as of January 2025 was $1,633 per month, according to research from Gensler and Pew Charitable Trusts.

The median price of a home shot up more than 6% in March to $380,000, according to a report last month from the Illinois Realtors. It also said 1,812 homes sold in Chicago, slightly up year over year, when 1,804 homes were sold.

Stephanie Cutter, a Realtor at Coldwell Banker, said tariffs will likely make new construction more expensive and less frequent.

Cutter advises those looking to sell to consider more than just their interest rate. Refinancing is also an option, if rates drop.

Mast’s biggest worry is tariffs creating a “stagflationary effect,” which includes high inflation, slow economic growth and unemployment.

title: Apple estimates tariffs will add US$900 million to costs in June quarter; business in Vietnam to be affected
content: Apple CEO Tim Cook has outlined profound changes to the company's supply chain to minimise the impact of President Donald Trump's trade war.
resumen: Apple estimates that tariffs will add about US$900 million in costs to the quarter ending in June if rates do not change. Apple shares were down 3.8% after the company released quarterly results. Apple executives said that the company expects low-to-mid single-digit revenue growth during its fiscal third quarter, which is in line with analyst expectations of 4.28% growth to $89.45 billion, according to LSEG data. Apple did predict a hit to gross margins, which it said will be 45.5% to 46.5% in its fiscal third quarter, which is below analyst estimates of 46.58%, according to LSEG data. The Cupertino, California-based company said sales and profit for the fiscal second quarter ended March 29 were $95.36 billion and $1.65 per share, respectively, compared with analyst estimates of $94.68 billion and $1.63 per share, according to LSEG data. Sales of iPhones were $46.84 billion, compared with estimates of $46.17 billion, according to LSEG data. Apple saw "limited impact" from tariffs during the fiscal second quarter as the company shifted its supply chains and inventory. For the quarter ending in June, "assuming the current global tariff rates, policies and applications do not change for the balance of the quarter and no new tariffs are added, we estimate the impact to add $900 million to our cost." The majority of iPhones sold in the U.S. in the current quarter will come from India, and the majority of iPads, Macs and Apple Watches will come from Vietnam. The vast majority of Apple products for markets outside the U.S. will continue to come from China. Apple said sales in its Greater China segment fell to $16 billion, better than analyst expectations of $15.9 billion, according to data from Visible Alpha. Apple said sales in its services business were $26.65 billion, compared with estimates of $26.69 billion, according to LSEG data. Apple now has more than 1 billion paid subscriptions on its platform. In Apple's accessories and wearables segment, which includes products such as AirPods, revenue was $7.52 billion, compared with estimates of $7.85 billion, according to LSEG. Sales of iPads and Macs were $6.40 billion and $7.95 billion, respectively, compared with analyst expectations of $6.07 billion and $7.92 billion. Apple will increase its cash dividend by 4% to 26 cents per share and that its board has authorized an additional $100 billion for its stock buyback program.

title: Trump 100 days: What Kansas has seen under the president's second term
content: Kansas governor criticized President Donald Trump as the administration completes its first 100 days as chaotic.
resumen:
President Donald Trump entered his second term with a flurry of executive orders, signing 144 within his first 100 days.

Trump's record-breaking 144 executive orders within 100 days ― 45 more than the second most prolific signer of executive orders, Franklin D. Roosevelt ― has been used to fulfil promises made on the campaign trail.

That includes the establishment of the Department of Government Efficiency which resulted in the mass firing of federal employees, loss of federal grants nationwide to nonprofits and service organizations and rollback of DEI programs.

Among other 100 day changes were:

*   Executive order ending birthright citizenship, guaranteed in the Constitution's 14th Amendment. The U.S. Supreme Court was asked to weigh in on the issue.
*   Decrease in the number of migrants crossing the U.S.'s southern border to lowest in 25 years.
*   Appointment of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. as U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services. Kennedy, a known vaccine skeptic, has thus far banned artificial food dies.
*   The imposition of tariffs impacting trade goods to the U.S.
*   Restructure of the White House press pool which eliminated the long-standing presence of the Associated Press, Reuters and Bloomberg.

In a statement made in her capacity as the chair of the Democratic Governors Association, Gov. Laura Kelly criticized Trump for “creating chaos" as the president's first 100 days in office ended with low approval ratings from voters across the nation.

Kansas’s sole Democratic Congressperson, Rep. Sharice Davids, D-Kansas, echoed Kelly’s assertion that Trump’s policies are chaotic and goes against the interests of working families.

Kansas’s Republican delegation to U.S. Congress gave a more optimistic assessment of Trump’s first 100 days, with Sen. Roger Marshall, R-Kansas, calling it the “rebirth of American greatness” in an online press conference.

In the press conference he noted the decrease in border crossings under Trump’s presidency, the number of deportations processed, DOGE cuts and reduced rates of inflation.

Sen. Jerry Moran, R-Kansas, praised Trump's handling of the border and immigration.

U.S. Congressman Tracey Mann, R-Kansas, also settled on the theme of “promises made, promises kept,” in a social media post celebrating Trump’s 100th day in office.

Freshman Republican Congressman Derek Schmidt, R-Kansas, also touted the border, inflation, energy production, cutting federal spending and “establishing peace through strength” in a post celebrating Trump’s 100th day.

Rep. Ron Estes, R-Kansas, celebrated reduced border crossings, the release of Israeli hostages, spending cuts and investment into the private sector in a post about Trump’s return to office.

USA TODAY reported that Trump's approval rating was at 42% on his 100th day in office, the lowest of any newly elected president in over 50 years.

The poll by NPR/PBS News/ Marist, released on April 29 surveyed adults between April 21 and April 23. It found that Trump received a failing grade among half the respondents.

The poll showed half of the respondents felt the country was changing "for the worse," while 7% said the country is making no change at all.

Among the topics that swayed the poll respondents were immigration and the economy. Fifty-five percent said they did not like the president's handling of the economy while 42% of Americans disapproved of his work on immigration.

title: Xiaomi, Oppo, OnePlus and Other Chinese OEMs May Ditch Android as Trump’s Trade War Escalates
content: As President Donald Trump ramps up his renewed trade war with China, some of the world’s largest smartphone brands are quietly preparing for a future ...
resumen: Major Chinese manufacturers — Xiaomi, Oppo, Vivo, OnePlus, and Huawei — are reportedly exploring a Google-free Android alternative, aiming to reduce reliance on US technology amid rising political tensions. During Trump’s previous term, Huawei was blacklisted, cutting it off from US software, services, and even hardware — including the Google Play Store, which crippled its global smartphone business. Industry insiders claim that Xiaomi’s upcoming HyperOS 3 might lay the groundwork for this new platform. Huawei responded to US sanctions by launching HarmonyOS, which eventually removed Android compatibility entirely. According to Q1 2025 data, Xiaomi leads China’s smartphone market, followed by Huawei, Oppo, and Vivo. Collectively, they represent two-thirds of domestic shipments and hold a significant global market share. Xiaomi has also been the third biggest phone maker globally for quite a while. If even a portion of these brands launch phones without Google services, it could trigger one of the largest software ecosystem shifts in smartphone history, affecting billions of users worldwide.

title: Donald Trump y sus primeros 100 días de gobierno: Política exterior respecto a los aranceles aduaneros
content: El segundo mandato del presidente de los Estados Unidos ha comenzado intensamente en numerosas áreas de la política exterior, con marchas y contramarchas en el caso de la imposición de aranceles a los ...
resumen:
El segundo mandato de Donald Trump ha comenzado intensamente en numerosas áreas de la política exterior, con marchas y contramarchas en la imposición de aranceles a los bienes importados.

Trump superó a Roosevelt con 142 órdenes ejecutivas en sus primeros 100 días, con acciones que van desde la imposición de aranceles a los bienes importados a medidas de inmigración y control fronterizo, así como órdenes relacionadas a la defensa nacional y la política exterior.

La agenda de Trump en política externa ha sido tan intensa que varios analistas ya definen a la misma como la Doctrina Trump de política exterior.

La política exterior comercial del gobierno de Trump se basa en la premisa de que los Estados Unidos ha sido abusado económicamente por otros países, tanto aliados como adversarios, por numerosos años, principalmente China.

La imposición de aranceles aduaneros a productos de otros países, sobre todo a los provenientes de China, es el tema que ya les afecta, y les afectará aún más en los próximos meses.

Trump publicó una solicitada en el New York Times en la década de 1980, argumentando que Estados Unidos debía imponer aranceles aduaneros a Japón.

Trump se sintió al inicio plenamente libre de imponer su agenda pública en materia de aranceles, pero terminó prorrogando varias veces los aranceles a México y Canadá.

El 2 de abril, anunció la imposición de aranceles “recíprocos” a todos los países del mundo, pero suspendió los mismos por 90 días para todas las naciones, excepto China.

Las Bolsas llegaron a caer 20%, y cayeron también la cotización del dólar y el precio de los Bonos del Tesoro.

El Índice de Confianza del Consumidor de la Universidad de Michigan cayó por cuarto mes consecutivo, un 8% en el último informe.

Las expectativas han caído 32% desde enero, la mayor caída porcentual trimestral observada desde la recesión de 1990.

La aprobación pública de Trump ha sufrido un sustancial descenso, con la encuestadora YouGov reportando un 41% de aprobación y 53% de desaprobación.

El Buró Nacional de Investigación Económica informó que la economía cayó un 0.3% en el trimestre enero-marzo, muy por debajo del 0.8% de crecimiento que marcaba el consenso de los analistas económicos, y significativamente menos que el 2.4% de crecimiento del trimestre Octubre-diciembre de 2024.

La importación de bienes subió 47%.

Trump retrocedió, y suspendió los aranceles recíprocos con todos los países del mundo excepto China, e incluso dio señales de querer negociar con el gobierno chino.

China manifestó que está dispuesta a negociar.

Las grandes empresas estadounidenses están contactando directamente a la Administración de Trump para conseguir excepciones, como la que logró el sector automotriz respecto a los aranceles al acero y las autopartes.

Los aranceles podrían derivar en protestas masivas e incluso en una contracción fuerte del gasto del consumidor, lo cual podría conllevar una recesión, o al menos una desaceleración económica.

Los aranceles específicos para cada país del presidente Trump se basan en la Ley de Poderes Económicos de Emergencia Internacional (IEEPA) de 1977.

La Ley de Emergencias Nacionales (NEA) exige que el Presidente presente informes periódicos al Congreso sobre las circunstancias, amenazas y medidas adoptadas en virtud de la IEEPA.

Las cámaras del Congreso también pueden revocar la declaración de emergencia nacional subyacente mediante la promulgación de una resolución conjunta de desaprobación.

title: Wall Street stocks buoyed by strong economic data, possible US-China trade talks
content: Wall Street stocks advanced on Friday (May 2), notching the second straight week of gains, helped by strong economic data and potential easing of trade tensions between the US and China.
resumen:
Wall Street stocks advanced on Friday (May 2), notching the second straight week of gains, helped by strong economic data and potential easing of trade tensions between the US and China.

The US economy added 177,000 jobs in April, exceeding expectations, while the unemployment rate held steady at 4.2 per cent.

The S&P 500 has erased the slump set off by Trump's "Liberation Day" tariff announcement on Apr 2, with the index now up 0.3 per cent since the close of Apr 2.

The S&P 500 also reached its ninth consecutive session of gains, matching a winning streak from 2004, while the Dow hit a nine-day winning streak for the first since December 2023. For the week, the S&P 500 gained 2.9 per cent, the Dow climbed 3 per cent, and the Nasdaq added 3.43 per cent.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 564.47 points, or 1.39 per cent, to 41,317.43, the S&P 500 gained 82.54 points, or 1.47 per cent, to 5,686.68 and the Nasdaq Composite gained 266.99 points, or 1.51 per cent, to 17,977.73.

Apple fell nearly 4 per cent after the iPhone maker trimmed its share buyback program by US$10 billion and CEO Tim Cook told analysts that tariffs could add about US$900 million in costs this quarter.

Meta Platform rose 4.3 per cent and Nvidia gained 2.6 per cent. Amazon dipped 0.1 per cent.

Chevron rose 1.6 per cent and ExxonMobil gained 0.4 per cent.

Block slumped 20 per cent after cutting its profit forecast for 2025.

Video game maker Take-Two Interactive fell nearly 7 per cent after it delayed the release of "Grand Theft Auto VI" to May 2026.

Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a 3.81-to-1 ratio on the NYSE. There were 144 new highs and 47 new lows on the NYSE.

The S&P 500 posted 12 new 52-week highs and 3 new lows while the Nasdaq Composite recorded 51 new highs and 38 new lows.

Volume on US exchanges was 15.99 billion shares, compared with the 19.3 billion average for the full session over the last 20 trading days.

title: Trump y los aranceles a las importaciones
content: Para los aranceles que Donald Trump está imponiendo de forma global, pero haciendo diferencia entre algunos países, es fácil predecir las consecuencias, aunque no se tenga un set de datos para hacer ...
resumen:
Las autoridades de un país a veces toman decisiones con el objetivo de obtener un buen resultado para el mismo. Sin embargo, cuando las decisiones se toman buscando perjudicar a terceros, los efectos pueden revertirse y afectar al país que se quiere beneficiar.

Para los aranceles que Donald Trump está imponiendo de forma global, pero haciendo diferencia entre algunos países, es fácil predecir las consecuencias.

Las consecuencias serán peores para los Estados Unidos que para la República Dominicana.

Esta medida de Trump representa una gran oportunidad para la República Dominicana.

Esta medida puede afectar a todos los sectores exportadores, pero como economista agrícola, quiero enfocarme en el sector agropecuario.

A la República Dominicana se le presenta la oportunidad de aprovechar el arancel de solo un 10% a sus productos, en comparación con uno más alto a otros países.

Estos aranceles globales no tendrán un efecto para el país más allá de la inestabilidad e incertidumbre similar a la inflación.

Estos aranceles afectarán más a los consumidores en los Estados Unidos que a la República Dominicana.

Los exportadores de la República Dominicana no deben reducir los precios de exportación debido a estos aranceles.

Los ajustes deben ser hechos en el mercado de los Estados Unidos.

En la República Dominicana se debe seguir buscando la calidad y la competitividad para obtener la mayor participación del mercado estadounidense en comparación con otros países exportadores.

En el 2024, Estados Unidos exportó a República Dominicana un total de US$2,226.5 millones, mientras que sus importaciones desde la República Dominicana fueron de solo US$1,809.2 millones.

Esto significa un balance a favor de los Estados Unidos de US$417 millones.

Cualquier medida similar que tome la República Dominicana en aranceles para solo productos agropecuarios también afectaría más las exportaciones de los Estados Unidos, afectando más su sector agropecuario.

Nuestro sector agropecuario dominicano no debe preocuparse.

La bola estará en la cancha de Estados Unidos y su sector comercial para reaccionar a los efectos negativos de estas medidas para sus consumidores.

title: Cómo Apple busca evitar los aranceles de Trump a China (y qué implica para Latinoamérica)
content: El gigante tecnológico dijo que los aranceles estadounidenses sumarán alrededor de US$900 millones a sus costos este trimestre.
resumen:
El gigante tecnológico dijo que los aranceles estadounidenses sumarán alrededor de US$900 millones a sus costos este trimestre.

Los dispositivos más populares del mundo –teléfonos, laptops, tabletas y relojes inteligentes– quedaron expuestos a un alza considerable de precios en Estados Unidos.

El presidente Donald Trump impuso un arancel del 145% a los productos importados desde China, aunque luego eximió temporalmente de ese impuesto a los electrónicos.

Algunos analistas afirmaban semanas atrás que si los costos de importación eran trasladados a los consumidores, los precios del iPhone en EUA podían aumentar cientos de dólares.

Si los aranceles tienen un efecto sobre el valor del dólar, podría resultar más caro importar iPhones y otros dispositivos en todo el mundo.

Los usuarios podrían tener que firmar contratos más largos con las operadoras telefónicas para distribuir en el tiempo el valor del dispositivo.

Ben Wood, de la investigadora de mercado británica CCS Insight, cree que "podríamos ver contratos de cinco años" en 2025.

EUA es un mercado importante para el iPhone y Apple vendió más de la mitad del total de smartphones comercializados el año pasado en ese país, según la consultora del mercado tecnológico Counterpoint Research.

Hasta el 80% de los iPhones de Apple destinados a la venta en EUA se fabrican en China, y el 20% restante en India.

Samsung fabrica más del 60% de sus teléfonos en Vietnam, de acuerdo a Counterpoint Research.

Trump y sus asesores han afirmado que el objetivo de sus aranceles es fomentar una mayor producción en EUA.

El Departamento de Comercio tiene hasta 270 días para hacer sus recomendaciones.

Stephen Miller, subjefe de gabinete de política de la Casa Blanca, advirtió en X que estos productos electrónicos aún están sujetos al arancel del 20% impuesto a China por el fentanilo.

La Casa Blanca indicó que las exenciones se implementaron para garantizar que las empresas tuvieran más tiempo para trasladar la producción a EUA.

La secretaria de prensa de la Casa Blanca, Karoline Leavitt, declaró que las empresas se están apresurando a trasladar su producción a EUA.

Apple comprometió una inversión de US$500.000 millones en EUA en febrero.

El analista Dan Ives, de Wedbush Securities, afirmó que trasladar partes de su cadena de suministro desde centros de fabricación más económicos en Asia a EUA requeriría mucho tiempo y dinero.

Se necesitarían tres años y US$30.000 millones para trasladar incluso el 10% de su cadena de suministro de Asia a EUA.

Algunas estimaciones sugieren que los precios del iPhone en EUA podrían hasta triplicarse si los costos se trasladaran a los consumidores.

El banco de inversión UBS estimó que el precio de un iPhone 16 Pro Max fabricado en China con 256 GB de almacenamiento se dispararía de US$1.199 a US$1.999 más impuestos.

Analistas estimaron que con aranceles de 125% a los productos chinos, el iPhone más caro podría aumentar su precio al consumidor en US$800 en EUA.

El iPhone 16 Pro de 128 GB de almacenamiento, fabricado en India, podría aumentar su precio en un 5%, de US$999 a US$1.046 más impuestos.

El precio de un iPhone "Hecho en EUA" podría dispararse a US$3.500.

Apple anunció que mudará la producción de la mayor parte de los iPhones y demás dispositivos que vende en EUA y ya no se fabricarán en China.

Tim Cook, director ejecutivo de Apple, dijo que para el trimestre que termina en junio, la mayoría de los iPhones vendidos en EUA provendrán de India, y que Vietnam será el país de origen de casi todos los iPad, Mac, Apple Watch y AirPods vendidos en EUA.

Trasladar las líneas de producción a India requerirá tiempo y una inversión de miles de millones de dólares.

Shanti Kelemen, directora de inversiones de M&G Wealth, señaló que seguirán existiendo aranceles que afecten a las cadenas de suministro de Apple y un costo para trasladarlas y construir nuevas fábricas.

Los iPhone que se importen desde EUA pasarán a ser fabricados en India.

Patrick Moorhead, director ejecutivo de Moor Insights & Strategy, dijo que la decisión de Apple fue "impresionante".

Tim Cook afirmó que solo China podía fabricar iPhones.

En América Latina, Apple tiene el 8% del mercado y es superada por competidores como Samsung, Xiaomi y Motorola, según la consultora de mercado Canalys.

Comprar un iPhone 16 Pro Max cuesta más de US$2.900 en Argentina, mientras que en Costa Rica se puede adquirir por poco más de US$1.300.

Los smartphones de Apple que lleguen a América Latina seguirán siendo fabricados en China, según la compañía.

Tim Cook aseguró que China seguirá siendo el país de origen de la gran mayoría de las ventas totales de productos fuera de EUA.

Los dispositivos de Apple que se venden en Latinoamérica no pasan antes por EUA, y por lo tanto no se les impone el sobrecosto de los aranceles de Trump.

El iPhone sigue siendo uno de los smartphones más caros del mercado, y marcas como Google y Samsung ofrecen en EUA teléfonos con características similares a un precio menor.

En América Latina, Xiaomi, Itel, Tecno, Infinix o Motorola también tienen dispositivos a precios más bajos.

title: 'Faced with Donald Trump, is global finance a stabilizing force or an enormous bubble on the verge of bursting?'
content: COLUMN. The US president plays with the nerves of the markets, with some accusing him of manipulating stock prices. The risk now is that the bubble will burst, writes economist Jézabel ...
resumen:
'Faced with Donald Trump, is global finance a stabilizing force or an enormous bubble on the verge of bursting?'.
The US president plays with the nerves of the markets, with some accusing him of manipulating stock prices.
The risk now is that the bubble will burst, writes economist Jézabel Couppey-Soubeyran in her column.
On the cover of its April 21 edition, the American magazine The New Yorker cleverly parodied a cult scene from Charlie Chaplin's film The Great Dictator (1940).
It depicts Donald Trump blowing into a globe balloon, spinning it on his thumb, bouncing it on his backside, before it explodes in his face.
This globe undoubtedly symbolizes the global economy that the president of the United States believes he can subject to the whims of his trade policy.
Trump declares a global trade war, plunging the US into economic uncertainty.
It can also be seen as the global financial system that Trump is playing with, with great nonchalance, at the pace of his tariff hikes and rollbacks.
After the Easter weekend, the American administration issued multiple statements aiming to calm spirits.
For many, this was a sign that the financial markets had sounded the end of the game.
Is global finance a solid stabilizing force or, on the contrary, an enormous bubble on the verge of bursting?.
Whether orchestrated or not, stock market indices have recently fluctuated with the announcements from the White House.
With each announcement of tariff increases, major stock exchanges plunged; with each announcement of a pause or retreat, they bounced back.
When tariffs rise, investors in financial markets expect global trade and overall economic activity to decline and revise their return expectations downward.
They lighten or reallocate their portfolios, resulting in more sellers than buyers in the market, which lowers the price of the most affected stocks and sectors.

title: A ‘big scam’? The end of a shipping loophole on China goods and what it means for consumers
content: A decades-old shipping loophole that made imported goods cheaper for customers and boosted foreign e-commerce platforms such as Shein and Temu sunsetted Friday.
resumen:
A decades-old shipping loophole that made imported goods cheaper for customers and boosted foreign e-commerce platforms such as Shein and Temu sunsetted Friday.

The 1938 provision, called the “de minimis” exception, formerly allowed shipments under $800 to enter the U.S. duty-free.

Trump last month signed an executive order eliminating the exemption for goods imported from China and Hong Kong.

Federal officials have previously accused China of fueling the U.S. fentanyl crisis by supplying fentanyl precursors to illicit drug manufacturers.

Trump’s move to restrict the shipping loophole is the latest in a slew of trade policy revisions poised to affect millions of consumers and small businesses who rely on low-cost goods from China.

Congress first introduced the “de mimimis” exception in 1938 as Section 321(a)(2)(C) of the Tariff Act of 1930.

In 2015, the figure rose for the last time to $800.

U.S. Customs and Border Protection processes “nearly 4 million duty-free de minimis shipments a day,” most of them coming from China and Hong Kong.

In the last fiscal year, 1.36 billion shipments came to the U.S. under the shipping exemption.

The White House said that Trump disqualified China from the trade loophole because of the country’s “deceptive shipping practices,” including an alleged pattern of smuggling “illicit substances” into the U.S. and bordering countries.

The president also argued the exemption has allowed Chinese e-commerce giants to edge U.S. retailers out of the market.

Trump said Wednesday during a Cabinet meeting: “It’s a big scam going on against our country against, really, small businesses and we’ve ended it.”

Foreign e-commerce platforms impacted by the loophole’s closure will probably pass price increases on to shoppers.

U.S. consumers who rely on such platforms for bargain-priced clothing and other household goods may struggle to shoulder new higher costs.

Trump said in an executive order that “de minimis” packages from other countries are also slated to lose their tariff exemption as soon as the government can develop a system to “expeditiously process and collect” the duties.

Shein has already raised its prices, with its top 100 products in the beauty and health category seeing an average increase of 51%.

Temu said in a statement to the Washington Post that it is moving to a “local fulfillment model,” with U.S. orders handled by sellers in the United States in an effort to sidestep tariffs.

Customers have already expressed disappointment about products being removed from their shopping carts because they were not certified “local” to the U.S.

Singapore-based Shein and China-owned Temu stand to lose significant business from U.S. consumers aggrieved by the price hikes and decreased product availability.

title: Warren Buffett warns the trade war will hurt America: 'Trade should not be a weapon'
content: The billionaire investor, now 94, also said he would be resigning as CEO at the end of the year. He spoke at Berkshire Hathaway's annual shareholder meeting known as "Woodstock for Capitalists." ...
resumen:
Warren Buffett announced his retirement and warned the trade war will hurt America.

Buffett, the billionaire investor and Berkshire Hathaway CEO, said on Saturday morning at his annual shareholder meeting in Omaha that the United States should not use trade as a weapon. He stated that the United States should trade with the rest of the world and do what it does best, and they should do what they do best.

Buffett, 94, announced that he would be stepping down as CEO at the end of the year, in favor of his long-designated successor, Greg Abel.

Berkshire Hathaway reported a sharp drop in quarterly profit from a year earlier and said it can't currently predict the tariffs' impact on its vast array of businesses and investments, but "it is reasonably possible there could be adverse consequences."

Buffett bought Berkshire Hathaway in 1965. Sixty years later, it's one of the largest companies in the world, operating businesses ranging from insurance and railroads to Dairy Queen and Duracell batteries. It's also a powerful investor in other companies, owning shares in Coca-Cola, Apple, American Express, and other big businesses.

title: Car Prices Expected to Rise as Tariffs on Parts Kick In
content: The tariffs are expected to shrink the supply of less expensive vehicles. Nearly 80 percent of cars priced at less than $30,000 will be subject to 25 percent tariffs, including popular vehicles like ...
resumen:
The United States imposed 25 percent tariffs on imported auto parts on Saturday. These tariffs, ordered by President Trump in March, follow the 25 percent levies on imported cars that took effect in early April. The tariffs on parts will not apply to components from Canada or Mexico if they meet the requirements of a North American trade agreement. Imported auto parts would not be subjected to other levies, like the ones on aluminum and steel. Companies that made cars in the United States would be exempted for two years from having to pay a portion of the tariffs for imported parts.

The tariffs have already pushed up new car prices. The tariffs are also expected to increase the cost of repairs and insurance premiums. Rising car prices will contribute to overall inflation.

Jim Farley, the chief executive of Ford Motor, stated that some parts are not available domestically. Automakers and suppliers say it will take years for them to relocate assembly lines. Mr. Trump has frequently changed his mind about the size of tariffs and how they should be applied. On Tuesday, he modified some of the rules to allow automakers to avoid paying duties on a portion of the components they import for two years.

Lenny LaRocca, U.S. automotive industry leader at the consulting firm KPMG, said that auto suppliers are already at thin margins and can’t afford the full cost of 25 percent tariffs.

The auto industry accounts for about 5 percent of Mexico’s gross domestic product and employs around one million people in the country. Vehicles and parts are by far Mexico’s largest exports to the United States. Marcelo Ebrard, Mexico’s economy minister, said that the situation is not as disadvantageous as many expected.

Flavio Volpe, the president of the Automotive Parts Manufacturers’ Association, said that the vehicles made in Canada will still be hit with tariffs when they are exported to the United States.

General Motors said that because of tariffs it was eliminating a third shift at a pickup truck assembly line in Oshawa, Ontario. Unifor said the reduction would eliminate about 700 union jobs and was likely to cause parts makers to lay off another 1,200 people. Prime Minister Mark Carney said that G.M.’s decision was a “terrible manifestation” of the economic crisis Mr. Trump’s tariffs had created for Canada.

Tesla and Ford are somewhat less vulnerable. Tesla manufactures all of the cars it sell in the United States in California and Texas. Ford says that it makes nearly 80 percent of the vehicles it sells in the United States domestically. General Motors will suffer more, analysts say, because imported parts account for a large proportion of the value of Chevrolets or Cadillacs made in the United States. G.M. also imports cars from Canada, Mexico and South Korea. G.M. disputed that assertion, saying that 80 percent of its parts will be exempt from tariffs. Volvo Cars, which has a factory in South Carolina but uses many parts from China, will also be hard hit. Rivian builds electric pickups in Illinois, but imports batteries from South Korea and China that will be subject to tariffs.

Nearly 80 percent of cars priced at less than $30,000 will be subject to 25 percent tariffs, according to Cox Automotive.

Ford, Hyundai and Volkswagen are among carmakers that have said they will not raise prices for several months. G.M. said on Thursday that the tariffs would cost it up to $5 billion this year. Other companies like Stellantis and Mercedes-Benz have told investors they can no longer make reliable predictions about sales and profit for 2025.

title: China abre la puerta a negociar con EEUU, pero con condiciones
content: Las autoridades de China afirmaron el viernes que evalúan una propuesta de negociación de Estados Unidos sobre la guerra comercial, pero insistieron en que el país norteamericano debe retirar en prime ...
resumen:
Las autoridades de China afirmaron el viernes que evalúan una propuesta de negociación de Estados Unidos sobre la guerra comercial, pero insisten en que el país norteamericano debe retirar en primer lugar los aranceles que han sacudido la economía mundial.

El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, gravó muchas de las importaciones chinas con gravámenes de hasta el 145%.

China respondió con tarifas del 125% sobre las importaciones estadounidenses.

Trump eximió de aranceles a productos como teléfonos inteligentes, semiconductores y computadoras.

El Ministerio de Comercio de China aseguró que fue la parte estadounidense quien dio el primer paso hacia un eventual diálogo.

China está actualmente evaluando la propuesta.

Pekín reclama pasos a Estados Unidos que demuestren sus buenas intenciones.

Trump decretó una suspensión de 90 días de estas tarifas recíprocas a decenas de países, pero las aumentó para China.

title: Los cien días que dañaron al mundo
content: Se han cumplido 100 días de gobierno de Donald Trump. No han sido banales ni silenciosos, tampoco prudentes y menos amables. En verdad nada de ello era esperable, el hombre llegó al gobierno de la pri ...
resumen:
Se han cumplido 100 días de gobierno de Donald Trump. El hombre llegó al gobierno de la principal potencia mundial anunciando ruido y furia, amenazó con cambiarlo todo.

En Estados Unidos mandaría él sin consultar a nadie, vengaría el supuesto abuso inferido a su nación durante 80 años por el resto del mundo a punta de aranceles, deportaría a los metecos que invadieron su territorio, golpearía a las élites intelectuales holgazanas que poblaban las universidades. Les diría a los europeos que “mientras los protegemos nos estafan en el comercio” y definiría a la Unión Europea como “sofocante, socialista y enemiga del libre mercado”.

Sus simpatías se han dirigido a hombres y mujeres fuertes sobre todo de extrema derecha, soberanistas nostálgicos de los viejos totalitarismos, mientras los líderes democráticos le parecen “desagradables”, Putin resulta ser un amigo y Netanyahu un amigo del alma.

La competencia con una China impávida se hace a través de aranceles gigantes, haciendo temblar la economía mundial. No tiene dudas que Canadá, fiel aliado de siempre, no merece ser un Estado independiente, quiere comprarse Groenlandia cueste lo que cueste además de recuperar el Canal de Panamá.

El reciente informe del Fondo Monetario Internacional proyecta un crecimiento mundial de 2, 8% para 2025, una revisión a la baja en relación con estimaciones anteriores. La razón principal reside en las tensiones comerciales fundamentalmente a través de la guerra arancelaria impulsada por Trump que ha afectado la economía mundial en particular el comercio internacional que crecerá solo el 1,7% en un océano de incertidumbre política y restricciones comerciales.

Después de la estupefacción inicial ha comenzado una resistencia interna y externa al trumpismo en su país y en buena parte del mundo. Los bolsillos de sus amigos multimillonarios han comenzado a adelgazarse. La globalización ha mostrado ser mucho más que el comercio. La ciencia y la tecnología es más universal de lo que Trump pensó e incluso un enviado de Dios, como él se autodefinió no es omnipotente, las instituciones democráticas comienzan a perder su parálisis inicial, las sedes del conocimiento sacan la voz, la opinión pública estadounidense tiende a cambiar y los indicadores de apoyo marcan cada vez menos, Europa tiende a despertar, el mundo comienza a sacudirse por doquier.

En los últimos días ha comenzado un cierto cambio de tono que tendrá idas y vueltas, pero que quizás lo haga morigerarse, aunque sea parcialmente. El hartazgo de las guerras, de la crueldad y del matonaje comienza a hacerse sentir.

Los tristes resultados de estos cien días han mostrado lo peligroso de un camino confrontacional y podrían abrir un camino de esperanza de un cambio en las relaciones internacionales.

title: Global factories struggle to overcome trump tariffs, uncertainty
content: FRANKFURT] More signs emerged in a wave of reports this week that global manufacturing is buckling from US President Donald Trump’s trade war. Read more at The Business Times.
resumen: Global manufacturing is struggling due to US President Donald Trump’s trade war. Purchasing manager indexes (PMI) across Asia, along with revised numbers in Europe on Friday (May 2), showed new or persisting contractions in factory activity in April. Few economies are avoiding the concussion of tariffs and paralysing uncertainty that’s engulfed the world economy one month after the US president announced widespread taxes on American imports. A report Thursday showed US manufacturing activity shrank by the most in five months, a day after data revealed Chinese factories slipped into the deepest contraction since December 2023. Factory sentiment is unlikely to turn around until there is clarity on where tariffs are headed. The on-off-on-off nature of the tariffs is creating huge uncertainty and that is leading to businesses sitting on their hands. The chances of a global recession will rise if uncertainty persists. The Asian reports on Friday were stark. Indexes for the region’s factory giants, including South Korea and Taiwan, slipped sharply amid falling orders and production cutbacks, according to S&P Global. In South-east Asia, activity shrank in Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia. India was an outlier with expansion in activity. The S&P Global manufacturing index reached a 32-month high in the euro area. Industrial activity remains highly exposed to US tariff policy. The JPMorgan Global Manufacturing index of future output declined in April to the lowest level since October 2022. Goods producers in emerging markets also took a hit. In South Africa, manufacturers turned more gloomy, blaming uncertainty fanned by global tariffs and domestic political strains. Absa Group’s PMI purchasing managers’ index fell to 44.7 in April – its sixth consecutive month in the contraction zone. Brazil’s manufacturing sector neared stagnation in April, with the PMI falling to 50.3, the weakest since December 2023. In Mexico, the decline was even more pronounced. Latin America’s second-largest economy saw its PMI plunge to 44.8 in April from 46.5 in March, marking its 10th consecutive month of contraction and the lowest reading since February 2021.

title: Potash miner K+S says US farmers to foot the bill for Trump’s tariffs
content: Germany’s K+S, which exports potash to U.S. farmers from Canada, on Thursday said it would pass any tariff-related costs onto customers, after its 2025 earnings forecast disappointed investors. K+S ...
resumen:
Germany’s K+S, which exports potash to U.S. farmers from Canada, on Thursday said it would pass any tariff-related costs onto customers, after its 2025 earnings forecast disappointed investors.

K+S produces around 8 million tonnes of potash products yearly, exporting about 300,000 tonnes to the United States mainly from Canada.

“The tariffs will be passed on one-to-one to costs, meaning the American farmer will ultimately foot the bill,” CEO Burkhard Lohr said in a press conference.

“If this becomes a sustained issue, we have the option to serve the U.S. market from Germany at lower costs, as there are currently no tariffs on European potash deliveries,” he added.

K+S forecast earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) of 500 million to 620 million euros (C$781.8 million and $C969.4 million) in 2025, compared with 557.7 million last year.

At its midpoint of 560 million euros, the outlook is above analysts’ average estimate of 537.5 million in a Vara poll.

Shares of the potash and salt miner were down around 5 per cent as of 10:25 GMT.

K+S topped market expectations for 2024 core earnings.

(1 euro = C$1.56).

title: Efectos de los aranceles sobre Costa Rica
content: Editorial | La poca diversificación de mercados de exportación hace que Costa Rica sea más vulnerable a los caprichos políticos de Estados Unidos.
resumen: Las políticas anunciadas por el gobierno de Donald Trump en torno a los aranceles sobre las importaciones estadounidenses han sumido al mundo en un ambiente de incertidumbre. Las restricciones indiscriminadas al comercio internacional tienen un efecto sobre el crecimiento económico, el poder adquisitivo de los consumidores y la generación de empleo. El PIB trimestral de Estados Unidos ya registró su primera contracción en los últimos tres años. Los precios de los productos afectados por los aranceles suben solamente en el país que imponen las restricciones al comercio. Los consumidores estadounidenses tendrán que pagar un mayor precio por los productos importados, aparte de los efectos sobre los artículos producidos dentro de su economía a causa de la disrupción en las cadenas de suministros, lo cual encarece los procesos productivos. Este incremento en precios afectará de manera permanente el poder adquisitivo de las familias, lo cual conduce a un menor consumo. El aumento temporal en la inflación retrasará una eventual reducción en la tasa de interés de referencia de la Reserva Federal de los Estados Unidos. El sector exportador de Costa Rica, ligado a regímenes especiales que representan cerca del 15% de la producción nacional, ha venido guiando el crecimiento económico, pero su dinamismo ha venido cayendo. La pérdida de competitividad en la atracción de turistas se debe, entre otras causas, a una política monetaria que favorece la apreciación cambiaria y a la crisis de inseguridad ciudadana. En el último año, a febrero 2025, mientras que la producción de las empresas con regímenes especiales creció 12,2 %, las empresas del régimen definitivo solo lo hicieron en 2,3%. Las presiones arancelarias podrían afectar más a las empresas del régimen definitivo que representan alrededor del 85% de la producción nacional. El hecho de que dependamos fuertemente de la economía estadounidense nos hace más vulnerables a los caprichos políticos de ese país. La diversificación de los mercados en los que vendemos nuestros bienes y servicios es importante. Los efectos de los aranceles afectarán la atracción de inversión extranjera directa, la demanda por nuestros productos y servicios y, con mayor severidad, la llegada de turistas estadounidenses, quienes representan 59% del total de visitantes que recibimos el año pasado. Los insumos médicos, que comprendieron 42% del total exportado, podrían verse afectados por los aranceles de Trump. Los organismos internacionales ya han alertado que el crecimiento económico en Costa Rica se reducirá en al menos 0,5% anual.

title: Berkshire Hathaway AGM live: 'A happy person lives longer', Warren Buffett to young investor
content: Berkshire Hathaway Annual Shareholder Meeting, scheduled for May 3, promises key insights from Warren Buffett, Greg Abel, and Ajit Jain. Ahead of the much awaited AGM, the Omaha-based conglomerate ...
resumen: The 2025 Berkshire Hathaway Annual Shareholder Meeting was held on May 3, 2025, with key insights from Warren Buffett, Greg Abel, and Ajit Jain. Berkshire Hathaway released its latest quarterly earnings, which were below estimates. Net earnings dropped to $4.6 billion. Class A share earnings fell to $3,200. Operating income came in at $9,641 million. Berkshire Hathaway, led by Warren Buffett, released the earnings for the first quarter of 2025. After a 63% fall in net profit, the investing giant issued a warning that tariffs and trade wars initiated by US President Donald Trump may affect the conglomerate's earnings. The Buffett Indicator slid down, indicating cheaper valuations, but Berkshire's own cash pile increased. Shares of Berkshire Hathaway have gained over 19% this year so far, compared to the 3% gains in S&P 500. Warren Buffett, at the meeting, emphasized the ongoing challenges in the insurance sector, describing it as inherently unpredictable. Insurance underwriting results were down significantly in the first quarter. Prices have declined this year, but risks have continued to rise. Insurance premiums in Nebraska have doubled over the past decade, even after accounting for inflation and storm-related losses, yet the business remains unprofitable. Buffett expressed confidence in Berkshire’s position. Ajit Jain acknowledged that growing competition from private equity firms has significantly impacted Berkshire Hathaway’s ability to invest in the insurance sector. Berkshire hasn’t completed any insurance-related deals in the past three to four years. Warren Buffett offered a personal and philosophical reflection, emphasizing his deep gratitude for having been born in the United States and his enduring optimism about the country’s future. Buffett voiced strong opposition to tariffs, calling them “a big mistake” and cautioning that trade policies should not be used as a weapon. Berkshire Hathaway’s record-high cash reserves total $335 billion. Buffett said the company is patiently waiting for the right moment to deploy capital. One key reason Berkshire Hathaway has been successful is its ability to move quickly when opportunity strikes. Buffett warned on fiscal policy risks in the US and abroad. Buffett said that his company would not really invest in a currency that is going to ‘hell’. Buffett touched upon increased exposure in the Japanese Yen. Buffett said that the government’s fiscal policies scare him. Buffett said that part of investing is looking for wrong and looking for what is missing. Buffett said that his company currently holds a giant pile of over $300 billion in cash. Buffett said that there are so many more opportunities in the US that present themselves in the security market than it does in real estate. Greg Abel emphasized the need for being prepared in order to act quickly. Ajit Jain said that AI is a game-changer. Buffett said that running the business of ‘investing’ is ‘very opportunistic’. Berkshire Hathaway is strengthening its partnerships with five major Japanese companies. Vice Chairman Greg Abel said the company is beginning with incremental engagements but anticipates much larger joint ventures over time. Chairman Warren Buffett echoed this sentiment, noting that Berkshire has no intention of changing how the companies operate, praising their existing success. Berkshire Hathaway reported $1.1 billion in first-quarter losses tied to the wildfires in Southern California. As of March 31, 69% of the total fair value of Berkshire Hathaway’s equity portfolio was concentrated in just five companies: American Express, Apple, Bank of America, Chevron, and Coca-Cola. By the end of the first quarter, Berkshire held approximately 151.6 million shares of American Express, representing a 21.6% ownership stake in the company.
